English: Alamu open your ears properly and listen to me...'
Yoruba: Àlàmú, la etí rẹ dáadáa kí o gbọ́ mi..."

English: But, did Alamu listen? Did he ever listen?
Yoruba: Àmọ́, ṣé Àlàmú gbọ́? Ṣé ó gbọ́ rí?

English: Here was the result of closing ears to the voice of wisdom and experience.
Yoruba: Àbájáde kíkọ etí dídi sí ohùn ọgbọ́n àti ìrírí rè é.

English: Learning this bitter experience might makes the scales fall from his eyes.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀kọ́ láti inú ìrírí kíkorò yìí lè mú kì ìpẹ́ojú rẹ̀ sí.

English: Ever since Mama arrived, she'd been avoiding talking to Labake directly, even eating her food.
Yoruba: Láti ìgbà tí màmá ti dé, ó ti ń yẹra láti bá Làbákẹ́ sọ̀rọ̀ tààrà, títí mọ́ oúnjẹ rẹ̀ ní jíjẹ.

English: She'd been feeding on the eko and the gari she brought from the district.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀kọ àti gaàrí tí ó gbé wá láti ilé ni ó ń jẹ.

English: With the exception of the period-of-the-day casual greetings and some occasional tip-of-the-tongue remarks to Mama.
Yoruba: Yàtọ̀ sí ti ìkíni àsìkò àti ìbániṣọ̀rọ̀ orí ahọ́n, Làbákẹ́ náà kò kọjá ààyè rẹ̀.

English: Umpire' had not been as vigilant as before.
Yoruba: "Onídàájọ́" náà kò ráyè ṣọ́ wọn bí i ti tẹ́lẹ̀.

English: His own present problem was enough for him.
Yoruba: Ìṣòro tó bá a lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ tó fún un.

English: He, therefore, had no time to watch the game anymore.
Yoruba: Fún ìdí èyí, kò ní ààyè láti wo ìran náà mọ́.

English: There were rough kicks and foul play - a lot of blows below the belt!
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ ìgbákúgbàá àti àṣì gbá ni wọ́n ń gbá pẹ̀lú ìkúùkù abẹ́nú tó rú òfin eré.

English: As Labake went about the household business, Mama's menacing gaze chased her all about - into, the toilet, into the bedroom, into the kitchen and finally into her bedroom, where Mama's gaze seemed to have pinned her down!
Yoruba: Gbogbo bí Làbákẹ́ ṣe ń siṣẹ́ ilé, màmá ń fi ìwò ìyọnu lé e ká, wọ ilé ìgbọ̀nsẹ̀, wọ balùwẹ̀, wọ ilé ìdáná, àti parí parí ẹ̀, lọ sínú yàrá rẹ̀, níbi tí wíwò màmá dè é mọ́!

English: And now, Mama jumped up from her seat and raced to Labake's room.
Yoruba: Nísinsìnyí, màmá fò sókè láti orí ìjókòó rẹ̀ ó sì sáré lọ sí yàrá Làbákẹ́.

English: Soon she was standing face to face with her breathing fire and fury.
Yoruba: Láìpẹ́, ó ti ń dúró lójúkojú pẹ̀lú ẹ, tìrúnú-tìrúnú ni ó fi ń mí.

English: The time had come to speak up!
Yoruba: Àsìkò ti tó láti lahùn!

English: Alamu had gone out, this was the right time to talk straight to the mischievous instrument of destruction at home.
Yoruba: Àlàmú ti jáde, àsìkò yìí ni ó dára láti sọ̀rọ̀ sí ohun èèlò ìparun tó wà nílé.

English: She would deal with her herself - her own way.
Yoruba: Á dá sẹ̀ríà fún un - lọ́nà tirẹ̀.

English: She was no longer going to keep quiet and watch Alamu's wife destroyed steadily by this agent of the invisible enemies.
Yoruba: Kò ní dạ́kẹ́ máa wò kí ayé Àlàmú bàjẹ́ poo láti ọwọ́ aṣojú àwọn ọ̀tá tí ò farahàn yìí.

English: 'Look at me'! Mama blared out, 'Look at me properly Labake! The cat been let out of the bag!'
Yoruba: "Wò mí!," Màmá sọ̀rọ̀ lójijì, "wò mí dáadáa Làbákẹ́! Àṣírí ti tú!"

English: 'What, Mama?'
Yoruba: "Kíni yẹn, màmá?"

English: 'Yes. Yes, Labake. It has been let out of the bag - the cat.
Yoruba: "Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni. Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, Làbákẹ́....ó ti tú - àṣírí.

English: If you don't know what that means, go back to your father and mother and ask.... Yes:
Yoruba: Bí o kò bá mọ ìtumọ̀ ìyẹn, padà lọ bá ìyá àti bàbá rẹ kí o bèèrè... Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni.

English: The wind has blown and it has exposed the anus of the hen!'
Yoruba: Afẹ́fẹ́ ti fẹ́, a ti rí fùrọ̀ adìyẹ!

English: 'Mama what are you talking about?'
Yoruba: "Kíni nǹkan tí ẹ̀ ń sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ẹ̀, màmá?"

English: 'You have become powerless from this moment onward'!
Yoruba: "Ipárẹ ti pin láti àkókò yìí lọ"!

English: 'Who Mama? Me? What is this?'
Yoruba: "Màmá tani? Èmi? Kí leléyìí?"

English: 'You know it all Labake! Stop pretending! Your wings have been cut this moment!
Yoruba: "O mọ gbogbo rẹ̀ Làbákẹ́! Yéé díbọ́n! Ìyẹ́ rẹ ti re báyìí!

English: Alamu is my only child - maybe you don't know - and nobody can take him from me. Your power is clipped from now on'.
Yoruba: Àlàmú ni ọmọ mi kan ṣoṣo - bí o ò bá sì mọ̀ - kò sí ẹnikẹ́ni tó lè gbà á lọ́wọ́ mi. Agbára rẹ ti tán bá yìí.

English: Mama had become transformed, she was no longer an ordinary human being.
Yoruba: Màmá ti wá paradà, kì í ṣe ènìyàn lásán mọ́.

English: Great tissue - thorns crawled out of the face of a ghost of vengeance suddenly let loose.
Yoruba: Iṣan ńlá ńlá farahàn lójú rẹ̀, ó sì jẹ́ kí ó jọ ẹlẹ́mìí èṣù, bí i ti òkú tó fẹ́ gbẹ̀san lójijì.

English: Labake looked at her mother-in-law, covered her face up with her palms and screamed.
Yoruba: Làbákẹ́ wojú ìyá ọkọ rẹ̀, ó fi àtẹ́lẹwọ́ rẹ̀ bojú ó sì hàn.

English: But Mama continued.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n màmá tẹ̀síwájú.

English: 'Labake.... Labake.... Look at me I say now!
Yoruba: Làbákẹ́...... Làbákẹ́.....wojú mi mo wí báyìí!

English: You no longer can look at my face!
Yoruba: Ìwo ò lè wojú mi mọ́!

English: See how a guilty mind behaves! I say your power is clipped!
Yoruba: Wo bí ọkàn ẹlẹ́ṣẹ̀ ṣè ń hùwà! Mo ní agbára rẹ ti tán!

English: The powers of those you are running errands for have also ended, this very minute.
Yoruba: Àgbàra àwọn tí ò ń jíṣẹ́ fún náà ti pin, ní ìṣẹ́jú yìí.

English: My fore-fathers have not slept in heaven. I thank them. I thank them.
Yoruba: Àwọn bàbá-ńlá mi ò sùn lọ́run. Mo dúpẹ́ lọ́wọ́ wọn. Mo dúpẹ́ lọ́wọ́ wọn.

English: I thank my fore-fathers, they are wide awake.
Yoruba: Mo dúpẹ́ lọ́wọ́ àwọn bàbá-ńlá mi, wọ́n lajú sílẹ̀.

English: And now they have intervened. So my son will be saved.'
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, wọ́n sì ti gbèjà mi. Fún ìdí èyí, ọmọ mi á rí ìgbàlà.

English: 'But.... But... But Mama. What is it Mama? Are you angry with me?
Yoruba: "Ṣùgbọ́n... ṣùgbọ́n... ṣùgbọ́n màmá. Kílódé? Màmá ṣe ẹ̀ ń bínú sí mi ni?"

English: 'The ancestors are angry with you Labake!
Yoruba: "Àwọn bàbá ńlá wa ń bínú sí ọ Làbákẹ́!

English: My fathers in heaven are angry with you!
Yoruba: Àwọn bàbá mi lọ́run ń bínú sí ọ!

English: Heaven itself is angry with you for what you are doing to kill my joy. The only thing i live for this world.'
Yoruba: Òrun gan-an ń bínú si ọ fún nǹkan tí ò ń ṣe láti pa ayọ̀ mi. Nǹkankan ṣoṣo tó jẹ́ n máa gbáyé."

English: 'Not me! I can't ever kill your joy Mama.'
Yoruba: "Èmi kọ́! Mi ò lè pa ayọ̀ yín láéláé Màmá."

English: 'But you can maim my joy - not so?
Yoruba: "Ṣùgbọ́n o lè pa álára - àbí bẹ́ẹ̀ kọ́?

English: I'll strip myself naked before you now and tear you to pieces with my teeth!
Yoruba: Màá já ara mi sí hòòhò níwájú ẹ báyìí, màá sì fi eyín mi ya ẹ́ sí wẹ́wẹ́!

English: Wait, let me strip myself naked!
Yoruba: Dúró, jẹ́ n já ara mi sí hòòhò!

English: Mama removed her head tie, removed her buba, took off her slippers, and threw down her wrapper! She held on for a while - breathing heavily....
Yoruba: "Màmá tú gèlè rẹ̀, ó bọ́ bùbá rẹ̀, ó bọ́ bàtà, ó sì ju ìró rẹ̀ sílẹ̀! Ó dúró díẹ̀ -ó ń mí lókè lókè...'

English: "I will remove this yeri and this agbeko and stand stark naked before you now!"
Yoruba: "Màá yọ yèrì àti àgbékọ́ yìí kúrò, màá sì dúró ní hòòhò ìbí ǹ bí níwájú rẹ báyìí."

English: It was a taboo for young person to gaze at the naked body of an old woman of Mama's age, whoever dared it was, in fact doomed. Doomed for ever.
Yoruba: Èèwọ sì ni fún ọ̀dọ́ láti wo ara àgbàlàgbà irú ọjọ́ orí màmá yìí, ẹni tí ó bá dán an wò, ìparun á dé bá a. Áparun títí láé.

English: A dreadful curse on such a fellow, the fellow will never live to old age and would die in unusual and mysterious circumstances.
Yoruba: Ègún burúkú lórí irú ẹni bẹ́ẹ̀. Irú ẹni bẹ́ẹ̀ kò ní tágbà, á sì kú ikú àrà ọ̀tọ̀.

English: Mama wanted to drive home her point properly before she would strip herself naked.
Yoruba: Màmá fẹ́ fìdí ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ̀ gúnlẹ̀ dáadáa kí ó tó di wí pé á já ara rẹ̀ sí hòòhò.

English: If it would be necessary, thereafter, to strip stark naked, she would do it.
Yoruba: Bí ó máa nílò, Lẹ́yìn náà láti já ara rẹ̀ sí ìhòòhò, á ṣe é.

English: "Look at me properly, Labake.... now you are ashamed and see the guilt all over you. Look...
Yoruba: "Wò mí dáadáa, Làbákẹ́... ojú ti ń tì ọ́ báyìí, wo ẹ̀bi ní gbogbo ara ẹ. Wòó...

English: Alamu will not die, he will get over the problem.
Yoruba: Àlàmú ò níí kú. Á borí gbogbo ìṣòro náà.

English: In the name of my fathers whose eyes never close in heaven.
Yoruba: Lórúkọ àwọn bàbá mi tí ò sùn lọ́run."

English: ""Mama..... Mama.... What problem? Alamu's problem... His problem, however heavy is my problem too... Oh Mama... How can you...
Yoruba: "Màmá... Màmá...ìṣòro wo? Ìṣòro Àlàmú ...ìṣòro rẹ̀ bó ti wù kí ó tó jẹ́ ìṣòro tèmi náà...hooo Màmá...... Báwo lẹ ṣe lè......."

English: "So you know that Alamu's problem is heavy?
Yoruba: Ṣé wí pé ìwọ mọ pé ìsòro Àlàmú wúwo?

English: So you know the weight of the problem you and your people are giving my son to carry?
Yoruba: Àṣé o mọ ìwọ̀n ìṣòro tí ìwọ àti àwọn ènìyàn rẹ ń fún ọmọ mi láti gbé?

English: Tell me, how heavy is it? Tell me! I know it is your wish that he be crushed under the heavy weight of this present problem. Look... Look... From this very minute, the heavy load has become yours to carry.
Yoruba: Sọ fún mi báwo ló ṣe wúwo tó? Sọ fún mi! Mo mọ̀ pé ìfẹ́ inú rẹ̀ nipé kí ẹrù ìṣòro wúwo náà pa á. Wòó....wòó... Láti ìṣẹ́jú yìí lọ, ẹrù wúwo náà ti di tìẹ ní gbígbé.

English: And i will open these my two eyes to witness how it will crush you... crush you along with those people who set you after my son."
Yoruba: Màá wá la ojú mi méjèèjì yìí sílẹ̀ láti rí bí ó ṣe máa wó pa ọ́, àti ìwọ àtàwọn tó rán ẹ sí ọmọ mi, á wó pa gbogbo yín.

English: "Who Mama? What are you talking about Mama? What is it? Just tell me. Let me know what you are really driving at."
Yoruba: "Tani Màmá? Màmá kí lẹ̀ ń sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ẹ? Kí ni nǹkan náà? Ẹ ṣáà sọ ọ́fún mi. Ẹ jẹ́ n mọ pàtó nǹkan tí ẹ̀ ń sọ."

English: "Pretender! Pretender ! you know what i am talking about.
Yoruba: "Alábòòsí! Alábòòsí! O mọ nǹkan tí mò ń sọ̀rọ̀ nípa rẹ̀.

English: You know everything. You know what am driving at.
Yoruba: Ó mọ̀ gbogbo rẹ̀. Ó mọ̀ ibi tí mò ń sọ̀rọ̀ lọ.

English: It is good that you have not completely killed my son before my arrival. It is good.
Yoruba: Ó tiẹ̀ dáa tí o ò tí ì pamí lọ́mọ kí ń tóó dé. Ó dáa.

English: You have only succeeded in turning his head - putting him out of his mind.
Yoruba: Ó kàn ṣe àṣeyọrí nínú yíyí i lórí - tí kò mọ̀ ohun tó ń ṣe mọ́.

English: There is an answer to that. His head will be put right again.
Yoruba: Ìdáhùn wá sí ìyẹn. Orí rẹ̀ á tún padà bọ̀ sípò.

English: His mind will be restored. And all of you would be put to shame."
Yoruba: Ọ̀kan rẹ̀ á padà bọ́ sípò. Ojú á sì ti gbogbo yín.

English: "All of us? Who? Me? Shame? Do I deserve shame in Alamu's house?"
Yoruba: "Gbogbo wá? Tani? Èmi? Ìtìjú? Ṣé ó yẹ kí ojú ti mí nínú ilé Àlàmú?."

English: "More than shame!" mama shouted back, breathing heavily, "More than that! If there is anything worse than shame.... That's what you deserve....
Yoruba: "Jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ!" Màmá pariwo padà, pẹ̀lú ìmí lókè-lókè, "Jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ! Tí nǹkan míìràn bá sì wà lẹ́yìn ìtìjú..... Nǹkan tí ó tọ́ sí ọ.

English: I will open my eyes like this to see how all of you would crawl regretfully before Esuniyi - in shame...
Yoruba: Mà á la ojú mi sílẹ̀ báyìí láti rí bí gbogbo yín á ṣe máa rá bàbà tí ẹ̀ ẹ́ máa kábàámọ̀ níwájú Èṣùníyì nínú ìtìjú.

English: What else can you wish for a woman who poisons the husband's food and drugs him? Tell me!
Yoruba: Kí ni nǹkan míìràn tí ó le fẹ́ fún obìnrin tó ń fi májèlé sí oúnjẹ ọkọ rẹ̀, tí ó ń gbé òògùn fúnun jẹ? Sọ fún mi!

English: What do you wish for a women who recites incantations to turn the head of the husband, to make the husband laugh like the hyena all about the house?"
Yoruba: Kí ni nǹkan tí o fẹ fún obìnrin tó ń pọfọ̀ láti yí orí ọkọ rẹ̀, láti jẹ́kí ọkọ máa rẹ́rìn-in bí i ìkoòkò káàkiri ilé?."

English: "Heavens"! Labake jumped up in agony. So high her head almost touched the bedroom ceiling. She flopped to the ground and started rolling in tears.
Yoruba: "Ọ̀run ò!" Làbákẹ́ fò sókè nínú ìrora. Ní gíga sókè tí orí rẹ̀ fẹ́rẹ̀ kan òkè àjà yàrá náà. Ó ṣubú lulẹ̀ ó sì bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í yí nínú omijé.

English: The end of the road had come! She would start packing immediately.
Yoruba: Òpin ọ̀nà náà ti dé! Á bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í palẹ̀mọ́ lẹ́sẹ̀kẹ́sẹ̀.

English: Pack all her things, hire a vehicle and leave Alamu's house - without looking back, without uttering a word of farewell to anybody not even to Alamu himself.
Yoruba: A kó àwọn ẹrù ẹ, á gba ṣáátà ọkọ̀, á sì kúrò nílé Àlàmú, láíwẹ̀yìn, láì lanu dágbére fún ẹnikẹ́ni títí mọ́ Àlàmú gan-an alára.

English: That was the most honourable thing to do in the circumstance. She'd been pushed to the wall.
Yoruba: Èyí ni nǹkan tó pọ́n ọn lé jù láti ṣe nínú irú ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yìí. Wọn ti sún un kan ògiri.

English: So this was what the old witch had been driving at? This wicked old witch of a mother-in-law!
Yoruba: Àsé ibi tí ìyá àjẹ́ àgbà yìí ń mú ọ̀rọ̀ lọ rè é. Ìyá àjẹ́ àgbà òṣìkà yìí tó pe ara rẹ̀ níyàá ọkọ.

English: Surely the end of the road had come! The marriage had broken down this very minute! See how easily a marriage could break!
Yoruba: Dájúdájú òpin ọ̀nà náà ti dé! Ìgbéyàwó náà ti wó lulẹ̀ ní ìsẹ́jú yìí! Wò bí ó ṣe rọrùn fún ìgbeyàwó láti túká!

English: An eccentric husband plus a wicked accusation.
Yoruba: Ọkọ aláágànnáayírí aparọ́mọ́ni takoni.

English: Then the end of the bond! Didn't somebody once say that the rope of love that holds husband and wife together was tough and strong?
Yoruba: Òpin okùn náàrè é! Ṣè bí wọ́n máa ń sọ pé okùn ìfẹ́ tó so ọkọ àti ìyàwó pọ̀ yió sì le?

English: Whoever said it, was wrong. Totally wrong. Here was her own rope, a mere fragile straw, snapping and giving way.
Yoruba: Àṣìsọ ni ẹníkẹni tí ó sọ ọ sọ. Àṣìsọ pátápátá ni. Okùn tirẹ̀ rè é, okùn jábútẹ́ lásán tí ó ti ń já.

English: Another fellow once said that marriage was a besieged castle - with some people struggling to get inside and others struggling to get out. That fellow was correct. Hundred per cent.
Yoruba: Ẹlòmíràn tilẹ̀ tí sọ ọ́ rí pé ìgbeyàwó jẹ́ ilé ogun pẹ̀lú àwọn ènìyàn tí wọn gbìyànjú láti wọlé tí àwọn mìíràn sì ń jìjàkadì láti jáde. Òtítọ́ ni ẹni náà sọ, òtítọ́ gidi ni.

English: She was going to get out now... Out! Out! Out of an accursed union! Out of a home where everybody had gone mad!
Yoruba: Òun náà máa jáde bá yìí. Jáde! Jáde! Jáde kúrò nínú ìsopọ̀ ègún! Jáde kúrò nínú ilé tí gbogbo èèyàn ti ya wèrè.

English: Mama was happy at the effect her accusation had created on Labake. That's how it is meant to be, she deserved it - even more.
Yoruba: Inú Màmá dún sí iṣẹ́ tí ìfẹ̀sùnkàn rẹ̀ ti ṣe lára Làbákẹ́. Bí ó ṣe yẹ kí ó ri nìyẹn, ohun ó tọ́ sí Làbáḱe nìyẹn, jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ pàápàá.

English: In fact, that was the beginning of what she would do to her.
Yoruba: Kódà, ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ gbogbo nǹkan tí ó fẹ́ ṣe fún un nìyẹn.

English: In the mean time, it would be better to forget about Labake and direct all her energy to solving Alamu's problem.
Yoruba: Sùgbọ́n fún ìgbà díẹ̀, á dára kí ó gbàgbé nípa Làbákẹ́, kí ó sì darí gbogbo agbára rẹ̀ sí wíwá ojútùú sí ìṣòro Àlàmú.

English: Her son needed urgent attention.
Yoruba: Ọmọ rẹ̀ nílò àmújútó kíákíá.

English: And there should be no further delay.
Yoruba: Ìdúró ò sí, ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ ò sí mọ́.

English: She knew how the problem was going to be solved. She knew where to go to solve Alamu's mental problem.
Yoruba: Ó mọ bí yóò ṣe yanjú ìṣòro náà. Ó mọ ibi tí ó lè lọ láti wá ojútùú sí ìṣòro aágànná Àlàmú.

English: Briefly, Mama closed her eyes saw herself inside Esuniyi's lunatic asylum way back home.
Yoruba: Láìfa ọ̀rọ̀ gùn, màmá ti dijú, ó sì rí ara rẹ̀ nínú ọgbà ìtọ́jú wèrè Èṣùníyì lábúlé.

English: The herbalist's asylum, was situated some five kilometres off Age village in an isolated clearing inside the deep forest. The yard was open and it stretched over some four acres of land, barricaded by high cemented walls topped with broken bottles and wire gauze.
Yoruba: Ọgbà oníṣègùn náà wà níbí i máìĺì márùn-ún sí Abúlé Àgé, tí a dátẹ̀ sínú igbó kìjikìji. Ọgbà náà fẹjú, ó sì wá lórí sarè ilẹ̀ mẹ́rin tí á fi ògiri gíga tí wọn fi sìmẹ́ǹtì rẹ́ yípo rẹ̀, tí wọ́n sì to ìgò àfọ́kù àti wáyà fẹ́léfẹ́lẹ́ sí i.

English: There was only one small entrance to Esuniyi's asylum and inside it, the herbalist planted the shady odan trees, numbering up to twelve stands.
Yoruba: Ẹnu ọ̀nà kékeré kan ló wọ ọgbà ìtọ́jú wèrè Èṣùníyì yìí, nínú rẹ̀ ni oníṣègùn náà gbin igi ọdán bí i méjìlá tó ṣíji bo ibẹ̀sí.

English: There were three mud buildings which housed about twenty inmates of the asylum. These inmates were always yelping and letting hell loose on the surrounding villages.
Yoruba: Ilé alámọ̀ mẹ́ta ni ó wà níbẹ̀, tí ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan sì gbà tó ogún aláágànàá. Wọ́n máa ń pariwo tí wọ́n sì ń farani àwọn ìlú tó yí wọn ká.

English: In a quick flash, the picture of Esuniyi, came in hand, and a ferocious look on his face, came to Mama.
Yoruba: Ní kíákíá, àwòrán Èṣùníyì pẹ̀lú ẹgba lọ́wọ́ àti ìwò ìrorò lójú rẹ̀ wá sórí Màmá.

English: She saw Esuniyi sweating, his eyes bulging and his whip mercilessly circling round the bodies of those stubborn ones who would not obey his instructions.
Yoruba: Ó rí i tí Èṣùníyì ń làágùn, tí ojú rẹ̀ràn tí àtòrì rẹ̀ sì ń dá sẹ̀ríà sí ara àwọn aláìgbọràn tí kò tẹ̀lé àṣẹ rẹ̀.

English: "Stop! Stop that noise!" Mama imagined Esuniyi shouting.
Yoruba: "Dákẹ́! Dákẹ́ ariwo yẹn!" Màmá ń rò ó bí Èṣùníyì tí ṣe ń pariwo.

English: "Remain standing where you are!" "Alright, it is time for food.
Yoruba: "Dúró sibí tí o wà! Ó dáa, àsìkò oúnjẹ rè é.

English: And you are all going to take the food sitting down on that wooden bench in the open yard.
Yoruba: Gbogbo yín sì máa gba oúnjẹ náà lórí ìjokòó lórí àga onígi tó wà nínú àgbàlá.

English: Not standing up like that... You hear me! You! Why are you still standing to eat your food?
Yoruba: Kì í ṣe lórí ìdúró bá yẹn.... O gbọ́ mi! Ìwọ! Kílódé tí ó ṣì ń dúró jẹun?"

English: Didn't you hear my instruction?"
Yoruba: "Ṣé o ò gbọ́ àṣẹ mi ni?"

English: Wham! Wham! Wham! Mama imagined Esuniyi's whip circling round the body of two of his patients.
Yoruba: "Wàmù!Wàmù!Wàmù!" Màmá ń rò ó bí pàṣán Èṣùníyì ṣe ń dún lára àwọn aláìsàn rẹ̀ méjì.

English: They quickly sat down on the wooden bench along with the others and continued eating their food, eyeing their master in fear.
Yoruba: Kíá ni wọ́n jókòó lórí àga onígi náà pẹ̀lú àwọn yóòkú wọ́n tí wọ́n sì bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí jẹ oúnjẹ wọn, tí wọn ń wojú onítọ́ọ̀jú wọn tìbẹ̀rù-tìbẹ̀rù.

English: Mama opened her eyes briefly and heaved a sigh. In another minute she closed them again - and other images came crowding into her memory....
Yoruba: Láìfa ọ̀rọ̀ gùn, Màmá lajú, ó sì mí àmíkàn. Ní ìṣẹ́jú mìíràn, ó tún pa ojú dé àwọn àwòrán mìíràn tún wá sí orí rẹ̀.......

English: Evening time in the asylum.... Mama saw, in her mind's eye, Esuniyi shaving the bushy hair of some of his patients.
Yoruba: Ní ọwọ́ ìrọ̀lẹ́ nínú ọgbà ìtọ́jú..... màmá tún fi ojú inú ọkàn rẹ̀ rí Èṣùníyì níbi tí ó ti ń fá irun tó kún bí igbó tó wà lórí aláìsàn rẹ̀.

English: Mama imagined herself holding Alamu by the handd, leading him to Esuniyi's asylum with tears in her eyes. And Esuniyi rushing out of his house with a whip to meet them.
Yoruba: Màmá rò ó bí òun ṣe fa Àlàmú lọ́wọ́, tí ó sì ń mú u lọ sí ọgbà ìtọ́jú Èṣùníyì pẹ̀lú omijé lójú. Àti bí Èṣúńiyì ṣe ń sáré bọ̀ níta láti pàdé e wọn pẹ̀lú pàsán lọ́wọ́.

English: In a minute, he was lashing out at Alamu with the long whip, beating him to submission, beating sense into his head to let him know he was in a house, a special house, where he had to conform...
Yoruba: Láàárín ìṣẹ́jú kan, ó ti ń kó o bo Àlàmú, tí ó ń nàá kí ara rẹ̀ lè balẹ̀, tí ó ń na ọgbọ́n sínú orí rẹ̀ kí ó lè mọ̀ pé inú ilé, ilé ọ̀tọ̀ tí ara rẹ̀ ti níláti balẹ̀ ní ó wà....

English: Next she saw Esuniyi shaving Alamu's own head and then chaining his hands and feet.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn èyí, ó tún rí i tí Èṣùníyì fá irun orí Àlàmú tí ó sì fi sẹkẹ́sẹkẹ̀ dè é tọwọ́ tẹsẹ̀.

English: That was where she would take her son, to get his present problem solved.
Yoruba: Ibẹ̀ ni á mú ọmọ rẹ̀ lọ, láti rí i pé ìṣòro rẹ̀ lọ́wọ́ lọ́wọ́ yìí yanjú.

English: And she knew too well that the problem would be solved there in a matter of weeks.
Yoruba: Ó sì mọ̀ dáadáa pé ìṣòro náà áníyanjú lááàrín ọ̀sẹ̀ mélòó kan.

English: Esuniyi was a master of his art. Mama had witnessed how he had solved three of such problems for the villagers....
Yoruba: Èṣúńiyì mọ̀ iṣẹ́ rẹ̀ dunjú. Màmá tirí bí ó ṣe yanjú irú ìṣòro bẹ́ẹ̀ mẹ́ta ní abúlé ....

English: And how his name was, consequently, on the lips of all the inhabitants of the one hundred and fifty villages of the district...
Yoruba: Àti bí wọ́n ṣe bẹ̀rẹ̀ si í jẹ orúkọ rẹ̀ lẹ́nu láàrin àwọn olùgbé abúlé bí i àádọ̀jọ tí ó wà ní agbègbè náà.....

English: Yes, Esuniyi cured the man from Kange... The young woman from Akokura, whom he later married...
Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, Èṣùníyì wo ọkùnrin ará Kange sàn, àti ọmọbìnrin tí ó wá láti Akókurà tí ó padà fẹ́.......

English: He restored the violent body from Jooda to normalcy. There were other cases Mama could not immediately remember.
Yoruba: Ó mú ara Jooda tí kò balẹ̀ padà bọ̀ sípò. Àwọn ìwòsàn mìíràn tí Màmá kò lè rántí ní kíákíá.

English: Esuniyi's aslylum was surrounded by a strange aura.
Yoruba: Àwọn ẹ̀mí àìrí kan ni ó yí ọgbà ìtọ́jú Èṣùníyì ká.

English: You would see him pounding something inside the morter, grinding something on the stone, chewing, boiling and burning one thing or the other.
Yoruba: Wà á rí i níbi tí ó ti ń gún nǹkankan lódó, à lọ nǹkankan lórí ọlọ, á jẹ́ nǹkan lẹ́nu, á bọ nǹkankan tàbí kí ó jó nǹkan mìíràn.

English: He would preserve the hair of his patients for medicinal purposes.
Yoruba: Á tọ́jú irun orí àwọn aláìsán rẹ̀ tí ó fáfún ìṣègùn.

English: Burn part of the hair, mix it with some herb and an oily substance, pour it back on the shaved heads and his patients and start reciting incantation for each one of them...
Yoruba: Á jó lára rẹ̀, á pò ó pọ̀ mọ́ àwọn ewé àti nǹkan ọlọ́ràá kan, á wá dà á padà sí orí àwọn aláìsàn rẹ̀ tí ó ti fá yìí, á wá bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí pọfọ̀ fún wọn lọ́kọ́ọ̀kan....

English: That was calling on the invisible power to enter the patients" heads, cool down their brain and restore normalcy to them.
Yoruba: Èyí tí ó túmọ̀ sí pípe agbára àìrí kan láti wọ orí àwọn aláìsàn náà, kí ó mú ọpọlọ wọn wálẹ̀, kí ó sì mú wọn bọ̀ sípò padà.

English: In the dead of the night he would chant special incantations against the enemies of his patients. The effect was usually dramatic.
Yoruba: Ní òru ọ̀gànjọ́, á pe àwọn ọfọ̀ ọ̀tọ̀ kan láti tako àwọn ọ̀tá àwọn aláìsàn rẹ̀. Isẹ́ òog̀un yìí sì máa ń dàbí i eré.

English: One by one the enemies were usually made to suffer for their atrocities. You would see them committing suicide by hanging on the tall araba or the iroko; you would see them plunging head-long into river or crawling on their knees to Esuniyi to beg for forgiveness.
Yoruba: Lọ́kọ̀ọ̀kan ni àwọn ọ̀tá náà máa jìyà ẹ̀sẹ̀ wọn. Wà á rí wọn níbi tí wọn tí pa ara wọn bí i kí wọ́n lọ so ara wọn kọ́ sórí igi ìrókò tàbí kí wọ́n rì sómi tàbí kí wọ́n máa wọ́ pẹ̀lú orúnkún wọn tí wọ́n sì ń tọrọ ìdàríjì lọ́dọ̀ Èṣùníyì.

English: Mama now looked at Labake, the way one looks at the stinking rubbish inside the rubbish pit and silently cursed her.
Yoruba: Màmá tún wo Làbákẹ́, tìkà-tẹ̀gbin .......

English: She raised up her head and saw Labake holding her son's hand inside the picture hanging on the wall of the sitting room and smiling. A treacherous smile on the face of a devil!
Yoruba: Ó gbójú sókè, ó sì rí fọ́tò Làbákẹ́ tí ó di ọwọ́ ọmọ rẹ̀ mú tí ó sì rẹ́rìn-ín músẹ́ lára ògiri yàrá ìgbàlejò wọn. Ẹ̀rín ìyàngì lójú èṣù.

English: All through the previous day when Mama confronted Labake, Alamu was not in. He went out to town and did not come back until late in the night when everybody had gone to sleep.
Yoruba: Ní gbogbo ìgbà tí Màmá dojúkọ Làbákẹ́ lánàá, Àlàmú kò sí nílé. Ó lọ sí ìgboro kò sì dé bọ̀rọ̀, ilẹ̀ ti ṣú púpọ̀ nígbà tí ó dé, tí gbogbo ènìyàn sì ti lọ sùn.

English: Quietly, he had sneaked inside, locked the door on himself and soon was snoring.
Yoruba: Ó yọ́ kẹ́lẹ́kẹ́lẹ́ wolé, ó sì ti ìlẹ̀kùn mọ́ ara rẹ̀, tí ó sì bẹ̀rẹ̀ si í hanrun láìpẹ́.

English: He woke up late in the morning to discover that Mama had thing inside her basket in preparation for the return journey to the district.
Yoruba: Ó pẹ́ láàárọ̀ kí ó tó jí, kí ó sì tó rí i wí pé Màmá ti múra, ó sì ti ń di apẹ̀rẹ̀ rẹ̀ ní ìmúra sílẹ̀ láti padà lọ sí abúlé.

English: Then he saw also that his breakfast was ready on the table.
Yoruba: Ó sì tún rí i wí pé oúnjẹ òwúrọ̀ rẹ̀ ti wà lórí tábílì.

English: He looked at his mother for a moment and turned his eyes to the food on the table the next minute. He seemed to be undecided... Well, there was no need for any hurry on the part of Mama.
Yoruba: Ó wo ìyá rẹ̀ díẹ̀, ó sì tún yíjú sí tábìlì ibi tí oúnjẹ wà ó jọ wí pé kò ì tí ì pinnu èyí tó fẹ́ ṣe.... Kò sí ìdí fún un láti kánjú ní ti Màmá.

English: He could talk to her after food. So, Alamu took his seat at table.
Yoruba: Ó lè bá wọn sọ̀rọ̀ lẹ́yìn oúnjẹ. Fún ìdí èyí, Àlàmú jókòó sídìí tábìlì.

English: Before Mama ever had the time to raise up her head, the first two spoonfuls of rice had disappeared inside Alamu's tummy!
Yoruba: Kí Màmá tó ráyè gbórí sókè, ṣíbí ìrẹsì méjì ti wọ ikùn rẹ̀.

English: And when Mama suddenly jumped up from her seat and said,
Yoruba: Nígbà náà ni màmá déédé fò sókè lórí ìjókòó rẹ̀ tí ó ní,

English: "Alamu! Alamu! I want to talk to you.... before your meal!... before your meal" - it was too late!The third spoon of rice was well ion its way down Alamu's throat.
Yoruba: "Àlàmú! Àlàmú! Mo fẹ́ báọ sọ̀rọ̀.....kí ó tó jẹun!.....kí o tó jẹun!" - Óti pẹ́ jù, ṣíbí ìrẹsì kẹ́ta ti wà lọ́nà ọ̀fun Àlàmú.

English: What was left for Mama to do was to move to the table and examine the soup in front of her son.
Yoruba: Nǹkan tí ó kù fún Màmá láti ṣe ni kí ó lọ sídìí tábìlì kí ó sì ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò ọbẹ̀ tí ó wà níwájú rẹ̀.

English: Egusi soup... Yes... But with some blackish substance inside it.
Yoruba: Ọbẹ̀ Ẹ̀gúsí.... Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni..... pẹ̀lú àwọn nǹkan dúdúdúdú nínú rẹ̀.

English: Her keen eyes saw it.
Yoruba: Ojú rẹ̀ mu, ó sì rí i.

English: The type Zenabu talked about.
Yoruba: Irú àwọn èyí ti Sènábù ń sọ.

English: Alamu glanced back strangely at his mother.
Yoruba: Àlàmú padà wo ìyá rẹ̀ ní ìwò tó ṣàjèjì.

English: Why all these fuss over egusi soup?
Yoruba: Kí ni gbogbo ìrọ̀kẹ̀kẹ̀ yìí, lórí ọbẹ̀ ẹ̀gúsí lásán?

English: "What is this you are eating Alamu?"
Yoruba: "Kí ni èyí tí ò ń jẹ́ yìí Àlàmú?"

English: The old woman asked - rather unnecessarily, but nonetheless meaningfully.
Yoruba: Ìyá àgbà náà bèèrè - ìbéèrè tí kò nílò, ṣúgbọ̀n tí ó nítumọ̀ sí i.

English: "I mean this?"
Yoruba: "Èyí ni mò ń sọ?"

English: "Soup Mama." Alamu laughed - the usual prolonged, full-throated laugh which two days ago left tears trickling down Mama's cheeks. Mama moaned.
Yoruba: " Ọbẹ̀ ni Màmá ," Àlàmú rẹ́rìn-ín bí ó ti máa ń rín-in, irú èyí tí ó rín níjẹta tí ó fa kí Màmá bú sẹ́kún. Màmá gbin.

English: "Alamu... Alamu... Are you sure this is ordinary soup?"
Yoruba: "Àlàmú... Àlàmú... ṣé ó dá ọ lójú pé ọbẹ̀ lásán ni èyí?

English: "Yes. Just soup Mama... Good soup. What else?"
Yoruba: "Bẹ́ẹ̀ni. Ọbẹ̀ ni Màmá... Ọbẹ̀ tó dára. Kí ló kù?,"

English: Mama gave the plate of soup a hard, suspicious stare and shook her head.
Yoruba: Màmá wo abọ́ ọbẹ̀ náà ní ìwò tó le, tí ó sì mú ìfura dání.

English: Yes... That black substance again. She saw it clearly - sprinkled all over the egusi soup...
Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ni......kiní dúdú yẹn tún ní. Ó rí i dáadáa - tí wọ́n wọ́nọn sórí ọbẹ̀ ègúsí náà...

English: Was Alamu blind? Surely he has been charmed... Was Alamu's nostrils blocked?
Yoruba: Ṣe ojú Àlàmú fọ́ ni? Dájúdájú wọ́n ti sàsí i...... ṣé ihò imú Àlàmú dí ni?

English: Mama cast a strange look at her son... Alamu continued to eat the rice and his mouth worked greedily.
Yoruba: Màmá tún wo ọmọ rẹ̀ kòòró... Àlàmú ń bá oúnjẹ rẹ̀ lọ ní jíjẹ, ẹnu rẹ̀ sì ń ṣe wọ̀mùwọ̀mù.

English: Mama heard the sound of his mouth and felt some pain - some sharp pain - inside her throat.
Yoruba: Màmá ń gbọ́ ohùn ẹnu Àlàmú bí ó ṣe ń dún, ọ̀nà ọ̀fun rẹ̀ sì dùn ún púpọ̀.

English: Alamu washed his rice down with water and noisily, continued munching on and on....
Yoruba: Àlàmú fi omi ti ìrẹsì rẹ̀ lọ sínú, ó sì tẹ̀síwájú pẹ̀lú oúnjẹ rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú dídún ẹnu rẹ̀...

English: What would he not eat? There was nothing Labake gave him that he would not eat!
Yoruba: Kí ni kò lè jẹ́? Kò sí nǹkan kí nǹkan tí Làbákẹ́ fún un tí kò lè jẹ!

English: If she prepared a bowl of excreta for him as food, Alamu would take it with relish and satisfaction.
Yoruba: Bí ó bá se abọ́ ìgbọ̀nṣẹ̀ kan fún un bi oúnjẹ, Àlàmú á jẹ ẹ́ pẹ̀lú ìgbádùn àti ìtẹ̀lọ́rùn.

English: If she gave him animal urine for water, Alamu would accept it and gulp it down his throat thirstily - and even thank her for it!
Yoruba: Bí ó bá gbé ìtọ̀ ẹranko fún un gẹ́gẹ́ bí omi Àlàmú á gbàá, á sì gbé e mì tòùngbẹ tòùngbẹ - á sì tún dúpẹ́ lọ́wọ́ rẹ̀ fún un.

English: Who would save him now? None but Esuniyi...
Yoruba: Ta ni yóò wá gbàálà báyìí? Kò sẹ́lòmíràn àfi Èṣúńiyì...

English: Esuniyi to the rescue! Delay could be dangerous.
Yoruba: Èṣùníyì ló lè gbà á! Ìjáfara léwu.

English: Alamu might soon take to the streets!
Yoruba: Àlàmú mà lè já sí títì láìpẹ́!

English: Mama grabbed her basket and stumbled out of the house.
Yoruba: Màmá ki apẹ̀rẹ̀ rẹ̀ mọ́lẹ̀ ó sì sá kúrò nínú ílé.

English: She knew that in a matter of days she would have to be back in town again to fetch Alamu.
Yoruba: Ó mọ̀ pé láàrin ọjọ́ mélòó kan, òun á ní láti padà wá sí ìgboro láti mú Àlàmú.

English: There should be no delay at all.
Yoruba: Kò gbọdọ̀ jáfara rárá.

English: The task before her was a task that must be accomplished - with dispatch.
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́ kíákíá ló wà níwáju rẹ̀.

English: As the days rolled by, Alamu sank deeper and deeper into own private world. So much so that Labake feared that her husband was soon going to go completely deaf and dumb - these in addition to the already heavy load of problems he was carrying on his shoulder. Some time ago, he had time to say one or two words in response to questions or requests from people, but not any longer.
Yoruba: Bí ọjọ́ ṣe ń gorí ọjọ́, Àlàmú túbọ̀ ń rì sínú ayé àdáwà rẹ̀. Ó pọ̀ tó bẹ́ẹ̀ tí Làbákẹ́ bẹ̀rù pé ọkọ òun á di odi àti adíti, èyí á wá kún ẹrù ìṣòro wúwo tó ti wà léjìká rẹ̀ tẹ́lẹ̀. Nígbà díẹ̀ sẹ́yìn, ó máa ń ráyè láti fèsì pẹ̀lú ọ̀rọ̀ kan tàbí méjì sí ìbèèrè tí wọn bá bi í, ṣùgbọ́n kò rí bẹ́è mọ́.

English: If anybody hissed now, Alamu no longer took notice; if anybody grumbled Alamu no more listened; if Labake shouted protests over cigarette he was smoking or the beer he was drinking, more frequently now than ever before, Alamu no longer cared.
Yoruba: Bí ẹnìkan bá pòṣé nísìnyí, Àlàmú ò ṣàkíyèsí mọ́; bí ẹnikẹ́ni bá kùn, Àlàmú kò tẹ́tí mọ́; bí Làbákẹ́ bá ń tẹnumọ́ ìkìlọ̀ rẹ̀ lórí sìgá tí ó ń fà tàbí ọtí tí ó ń mu léraléra ju ti tẹ́lẹ̀ lọ, kò kan Àlàmú mọ́.

English: Wading through the pyramid of files which he kept on top of an old cupboard in his room seemed now to be his main pre-occupation. He would bury his head inside the files for hours and leaf through their pages hastily ans anxiously. Then, pile the files up on the table by his side. Look away and heave a sigh. A few minutes later, he would go back, all over again, to the business of checking and rechecking the files, packing and re-packing them, arranging and re-arranging them. There was no end to it! At times, he would tear off a sheet or two from a particular file, read through it pointing to some sections of it with his forefinger and shaking his head, apparently as he stumbled on something that caught his interest.
Yoruba: Wíwo òkìtì àwọn fáìlì tí ó tọ́jú sókè kọ́bọ́ọ̀dù àtijọ́ kan nínú yàrá rẹ̀ wá di iṣẹ́fún un. A máa wo àwọn ìwé náàfún wákàtí púpọ̀, á sì tún máa ṣí àwọn ìwé náà láwẹ́láwẹ́ pẹ̀lú ìkánjú àti àníyàn. Lẹ́yìn náà á to àwọn ìwé náà jọ léra wọn sórí tábìlì ẹ̀gbẹ́ rẹ̀. Á gbójú kúrò á sì mí kanlẹ̀. Lẹ́yìn ìsẹ́jú díẹ̀, á padà sórí àwótúnwò fáìlì àti àkọtúnkọ pẹ̀lú àtòtúntò fáìlì wọ̀nyí. Kò sí òpin fún èyí! Nígbà mìíràn, á ya ojú ewé kan kúrò nínú ìwé náà, á wá máa ka àwọn ìpín kan pẹ̀lú ìka ìlábẹ̀ rẹ̀, á má a mirí, àgàgà tí ó bá bá nǹkan tí ó wùú pàdé níbẹ̀.

English: He suddenly had converted his own room into the big office of a self-styled Business Executive. Except that here he was his own Managing Director, his own Accountant, Auditor, Executive Officer, Typist and Messenger! It was another strange turn of events!
Yoruba: Ó ti déédé sọ yárà rẹ̀ di ọ́fíìsí ńlá tí a dáfún ìlò ara rẹ̀. Yàtọ̀ sí pé òun ni adarí pátápátá fún ara rẹ̀, Òun ni asírò owó fún ara rẹ̀, òun tún ni ayẹ̀wé-owó-wò, ọ̀gá pátápátá, àtẹ̀wé àti ìránsẹ́ ọ́fíìsì fún rarẹ̀! Eléyìí tún jẹ́ àyípadà kàyééfì.

English: Whenever Alamu was not wading through the files, he would be busy sipping his beer, puffing at his cigarette. Now, he no longer vomited, and the cigarette smoke no longer entered into his eyes or made him cough.
Yoruba: Bí Àlàmú kò bá sí nídì́í kí ó máa ṣíwèé lọ ṣíwèé bọ̀, á máa yọ́ ọtí rẹ̀ mu, yóò sì máa fín eruku sìgá rẹ̀. Kìí bì mọ́ báyìí, èéfín sìgá ò kó sí i lójú bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, kò sí mú un húkọ́ mọ́.

English: But he retained his strange laughter, and the effect of the alcohol was still very much with him. Which was one reason why he used to boast to himself that he could drive his car all through the streets of Ibadan with his eyes closed and following the left-hand lane! He could drink six bottles of acid, all at once to quench his thirst! He could, with only two quick steps, descend the stair cases of a two-storey building and get down to its ground floor without any scratch!
Yoruba: Sùgbọ́n ẹ̀rín àbàmì àláriwo rẹ̀ ṣì wà, isẹ́ ọtí kò sì kúrò lára rẹ̀. Èyí sì jẹ́ ìdí kan tí ó fi máa ń fọ́nnu pé òun lè wa ọkọ̀ ayọ́kẹ́lẹ́ rẹ̀ káàkiri gbogbo òpópónà Ìbàdàn tí òun bá díjú tí òun sì tẹ́lè ọ̀nà apá òsì! Ó lè mu ásíìdì ìgò mẹ́fà lẹ́ẹ̀kan láti pòùngbẹ! Ó lè fi ìgbésẹ̀ méjì bọ́lẹ̀ lórí àkàsọ̀ ilé alájà méjì, kí ò sì délẹ̀ láìfarapa!

English: How was one going to talk to the deaf? Somebody who was stone deaf? Labake tried it several times and failed.
Yoruba: Báwo ni ènìyàn ṣe fẹ́ bá adití sọ̀rọ̀? Ènìyàn tí etí rẹ̀ ti dí pa? Làbákẹ́ ti gbìyànjú láìmọye ìgbà ó sì ti kùnà.

English: "This you must hear Alamu'
Yoruba: Ó gbọ́dọ̀ gbọ́ èyí Àlàmú'

English: "Yea - ha ha ha ha! Hum hum! Ha ha!'
Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni- ha ha ha ! hun hun ! ha! ha!'

English: "Something that is very much on my mind ...'
Yoruba: Nǹkan tí ó ń gbé mi lọ́kàn ...'

English: "My! Em em -hum hum hum! - ha ha ha ha!'
Yoruba: Ẹm ẹm -mi hun hun hun - ha ha ha ha

English: "Listen please Alamu ... The other day Mama came ...'
Yoruba: Àlàmú jọ̀wọ́ tẹ́tí ... Ní ọjọ́ yẹn tí Màmá wá ...'

English: "Well - ha ha ha ha - hum hum - ha ha ha ha!" - then a frozen and far-away look on his face!
Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀-ha ha ha ha- hun hun - ha ha ha ha!' - Ìwò tí ó dí, tí ó sì jìnnà hàn lójú rẹ̀!

English: Tears gathered inside Labake's eyes, tears for Alamu, tears for what she suffered at the hands of Alamu's mother. How was Alamu going to know her ordeal? How was he going to know about the way his mother raved and raged? And then, those vicious accusations! Who was now going to vindicate her? She bottled all these up inside her mind. There was nobody to tell it to. Tears for this too ... And they came down in a flood ...
Yoruba: Omijé ṣarajọ sójú Làbákẹ́, omijé fún Àlàmú, omijé fún nǹkan tí ó jẹ́ níyà lọ́wọ́ ìyá Àlàmú. Báwo ni Àlàmú ṣe fẹ́ mọ̀ ohun tí ó là kọjá? Báwo ni yóò ṣe mọ̀ bí ìyá rẹ̀ ṣe sọ̀rọ̀ fitafita pẹ̀lú ìrunú? Àti àwọn ìfẹ̀sùnkàn búburú! Ta ló máa wá gbẹ̀rí rẹ̀ jẹ́? Ó gbé gbogbo èyí sọ́kàn. Kò sẹ́ni tí á bá sọ ọ́. Omijé fún èyí náà ... gọ̀ọ̀rọ̀gọ̀ ni ó sì dà wálẹ̀ bí odò ...

English: All Alamu cared for now was his files, his cigarettes and his beer. Nothing else.
Yoruba: Gbogbo ohun tí Àlàmú ń rí rò báyìí ò ju àwọn ìwé rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú sìgá àti ọtí rẹ̀. Kò sí nǹkan mìíràn mọ́.

English: There he was now at the bottle laughing his rib-splitting laughter, feeling really on top of the world!
Yoruba: Ibẹ̀ ló tún wà yìí, nídìí ìgò tí ó ń rín ẹ̀rín àrín kán-ní-hà rẹ̀, tí ó ṣe bí ìgbà tí gbogbo ayé wà ní ìkáwọ́ rẹ̀!

English: Tinu crawled to him and stood in front of him with her shaky, delicate soft tiny legs. The little girl smiled, showing her newly-formed front teeth, like she did to her mother, now instinctely asking her father to see and admire them.
Yoruba: Tinú rá lọ bá a, ó sì dúró síwájú rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ẹsẹ̀ ẹlẹgẹ́ kékeré rẹ̀ tí ó máa ń gbọ̀n. Ọmọ kékeré náà rẹ́rìn-ín músẹ́, ó ń sàfihàn eyín rẹ̀ tuntun tó sẹ̀ẹ̀hù bí ó ṣe ṣe sí ìyá rẹ̀, ó ń fi ọgbọ́n inú sọ fún bàbá rẹ̀ pé kí ó rí i kí ó sì jọ̀ ọ́ lójú.

English: Pa pa pa... Papa... Papapa...' Tinu babbled, She could now stand up straight on her two tiny legs without support. She was probably expecting daddy to congratulate her, before she would proceed to delivering a message - that message!
Yoruba: Bà bà bà ...bàbá...bababa...', Tinú ń sọ̀rọ̀ wẹ́wẹ́, Ó ti wá lè dá dúró lórí ẹsẹ̀ rẹ̀ tín-ín-rín-tín méjì yẹn láìsí ìrànwọ́. Ó ń dúró pé kí bàbá kì í kú orí ire, kí ó tó di wí pé ó tẹ̀síwájú láti jẹ́ isẹ́ kan - iṣẹ́ yẹn!

English: Alamu took a look at his daughter, and then took a look at the bottle of beer in front of him. He seemed to be holding a silent debate within himself over which one to choose... Alamu took another swig from the bottle. He seemed to prefer the bottle!
Yoruba: Àlàmú wo ọmọ rẹ̀, ó sì tún wo ìgò ọtí iwájú rẹ̀. Ó fẹ́ jọ pé ó ń jiyàn kẹ́lẹ́kẹ́lẹ́ lórí èyí tí yóò mú... Àlàmú gbé ọtí náà mu kíákíá, ó dàbí i pé ó fẹ́ ìgò ọtí náà ju ọmọ rẹ̀ lọ!

English: Then he recoiled and took a hateful look at the intruding little rat in front of him. It was a rather sullen, distant look, as if he was seeing his own child for the first time. He laughed a vociferous laughter. Little Tinu screamed. And crying, she scrambled away on all fours, not waiting to deliver any message.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn náà ó fa sẹ́yìn, ó sì wo eku kékeré iwájú rẹ̀ ní ìwò ìrira. Ó jẹ́ ìwò ìbínú tó jinná, bí ìgbà tí ó sẹ̀sẹ̀ ń rí ọmọ tirẹ̀fún ìgbà àkọ́kọ́. Ó rín ẹ̀rín aláriwo. Tinú kékeré han. Pẹ̀lú igbe ó rá kúrò láídúró jísẹ́ kankan.

English: Inside the matrimonial home, Labake literally saw a lurid cloud of smoke, Alamu had set his own home on fire, it appeared. And his mother has readily assisted, sprinkling petrol on the burning roof, to make it an inferno! And what would you do when you find yourself deep inside an inferno? When fire appeared on the mountain? Run, not so?
Yoruba: Nínú ilé ìgbéyàwó yìí, Làbákẹ́ rí àgbájọ èéfín tó pòkudu, Àlàmú ti dá iná sí ilé tirẹ̀ ganan, ó farahàn. Ìyá rẹ̀ sì ti ràn-án lọ́wọ́ láti wọ́n bẹntiróòlù sórí òrùlé tó ń jóná náà, láti sọ ọ́ di iná ńlá! Kí sì ni ènìyàn lè ṣe bí ó bá bá ara rẹ̀ nínú iná àìlééru báyìí? Bí iná bá ń jó lórí òkè gíga? Àfi kí ènìyàn sáré, àbí bẹ́ẹ̀kọ́?

English: Labake knew what to do. And she set about the business of packing cautiously and methodically. On the day she started, she stood on the balcony of the house and listened as Alamu revived the engine of his old Volkswagen in the garage and later backed the car out. She waited patiently until the car disappeared into the corner of the street with its usual trail of smoke and ear-splitting noise. The she ran back into the room.
Yoruba: Làbákẹ́ mọ ohun tí yóò ṣe. Ó sì bẹrẹ̀ ìpalẹ̀mọ́ lẹ́sẹẹsẹ àti létòlétò. Ní ọjọ́ tó bẹ̀rẹ̀, ó dúró sí ọ̀dẹ̀dẹ̀ ilé wọn, ó sì ń tẹ́tí sí bí Àlàmú ṣe ń ṣáná sí ẹ́ńjíìnì ọkọ̀ gbígbó rẹ̀ nínú ọgbà ìgbọ́kọ̀sí, nígbà tó sìyá ọkọ náà fẹ̀yìn rìn jáde. Ó dúró pẹ̀lú sùúrù pé kí ọkọ̀ náà pòórá sí kọ̀rọ̀ òpópònà pẹ̀lú èéfín àdámọ́ àti ariwo ajánilétí rẹ̀. Lẹ́yìn náà ni ó sáré wọ yàrá.

English: Inside the room, Labake flew at the standing hanger and started removing her clothes. Hurriedly, she pressed them inside the trunk boxes. Two cupboards inside the room contained trinklets and toiler articles and she started packing the items inside two empty raffia basket containers.
Yoruba: Nínú yàrá, Làbákẹ́ bọ́ ìfasokọ́sí, ó sì bẹ̀rẹ̀ si í i yọ àwọn aṣọ rẹ̀. Kíá, ó ti kó wọn sínú àpótí aṣọ. Ohun ẹ̀ṣọ́ ara ni ókún inú kọ́ńbọ́ọ̀dù méjì nínú yàrá náà, ó sì kó àwọn nǹkan inú rẹ̀ sínú apẹ̀rẹ̀ rafia òfìfo méjì ní kíákíá.

English: She stopped briefly and heaved a sigh ... Was she not runnign mad herself? Going crazy? How was she going to pack everything in the room without anybody's assistance? Her eyes caught the standing fan, the standing mirror and the movable wardrobe. Better to leave those till the last minute. They could be left where they are for the time being.
Yoruba: Ó dáwọ́ dúró díẹ̀, ó sì mí àmíkàn... ṣé òun fúnrarẹ̀ ò máa ya wèrè báyìí? Ṣé kò máa sínwín? Báwo ni yóò ṣe kó gbogbo nǹkan inú yàrá láìsẹni tí á ràn án lọ́wọ́? Ojú rẹ̀ lọ́ sí ibi fáánù adádúró, ibi dígí adádúró àti ilé ìfaṣọpamọ́sí tó ṣe é gbé. Á dáa kí ó fi gbogbo ìyẹn sílẹ̀ ná. Wọ́n ṣì lè wà níbi tí wọn wa yẹn ná.

English: An hour later, the sound of Alamu's car came to her ears ... Coming back home so soon today?
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn wákàtí kan, ohun ọkọ̀ Àlàmú tún wá sí etí rẹ̀ ... Ó tún tètè wálé lónìí?

English: Hurriedly Labake pushed the trunk boxes to the back of the door, closed the two cupboards, pressed the raffia baskets under the family bed, wiped the perspiration off her brow and came out of the room trying to look cool and collected ... Wasn't she running mad too? Wasn't she really going mad? She started breathing heavily.
Yoruba: Kíákíá ni Làbákẹ́ ti àwọn àpótí aṣọ náà sí ẹ̀yìn ilẹ̀kùn, ó pa pẹpẹ méjèèjì dé, ó ti àwọn apẹ̀ẹ̀rẹ̀ náàbọ abẹ́ ìbùsùn ẹbí, ó nu òógùn kúrò ní òkè ojú rẹ̀ ó sì jáde kúrò nínú yàrá, ó ń gbìyànjú láti ṣe dáadáa... Ṣe òun náà ò ti wá máa ya wèrè? Ṣe kò máa sínwín báyìí? Ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ si í mí kíkankíkan.

English: The following morning, she swung into real action, she dressed up, hooked her small handbag under her left armpit, and soon she was on the street hailing a taxi. As she waited for one she silently rehearsed the story she was soon going to relate. It must be neatly related convincingly. Nothing must be left out.
Yoruba: Lówùúrọ́ ọjọ́ kejì, ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ isẹ́ rẹ̀ ní pẹrẹu, ó múra, ó fi báàgì ìfàlọ́wọ́ sí abíyá apá òsì, láìpẹ́ ó ti wà ní òpòpónà tí ó ń pe kabúkabú. Bí ó ṣe ń dúró de kabúkabú ni ó ń ronú nǹkan tí yóò sọ. Ó gbọ́dọ̀ sọ̀rọ̀ dáadáa tí yóò dánilójú. Kò sì gbọdọ̀ yọ nǹkankan sílẹ̀.

English: It took Labake more than thirty minutes to get to her destination. Oke-Are was not too direct form Oke-Ado. There was the Beere traffic jam to put up with. The perennial "hold-up along Agbeni - Lebanon Street, not to talk of the menace of the danfo and taxi drivers around Ogunpa. The more direct Gege - Okefofo road had been blocked as a result of a deep trench dug by the Water men. The trench had been there for some two months but noiselessly into an annhs or so, and it appeared the Water men were in no hurry at all to fill it up. So, it was now the longer route which Labake took, but, finally she got to Oke-Ado and entered the lawyers" chambers. The signboard was imposing.
Yoruba: Ó gba Làbákẹ́ ni bí i ọgbọ̀n ìṣẹ́jú kí ó tó débi tó ń lọ. Òkè-Àrẹ kò lọ tààrà láti Òkè-Àdó. Ó sì ní láti kọjà níbi sún-kẹrẹ-fà-kẹrẹ ọkọ̀ ní Bẹẹrẹ. Èyí tó sì wà ní òpópònà Agbeni sí Lẹbanon ò gbẹ́yìn, kí a tó wásọ ti ìwàkuwà àwọn awakọ̀ dánfó àti kabúkabú lágbèègbè Ògùnpa. Ọ̀nà tí ó ṣe tààrà láti Gẹ́gẹ́ sí Òkèfòkò látàrí kòtò ńlá tí àwọn olómi gbẹ́ síbẹ̀. Ihò náà á ti máa lo bí i oṣù méjì tábì jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ, ó sì jọ wí pé àwọn olómi náà kò kánjú láti dí i pa. Fún ìdí èyí, ọ̀nà tí ó gùn jù ni Làbákẹ́ gbà, ṣùgbọ́n ó jàjà dé Òkè-Àdó, ó sì wọ ọ̀fìisi àwọn agbẹ́jọ́rò lọ. Pátákó ìjúwe náà mú ni lọ́kàn.

English: As she stepped into the receptionist's office, her heart started beating fast. She filled in the visitor's slip with trembling fingers, took a seat and looked round strangely, almost timidly. Everything in the lawyers" chambers followed a definitely rigid pattern; the way she was welcomed; the way answers were given to her requests.
Yoruba: Bí ó ṣe wọ inú ọ́fíìsi olùgbàlejò, ọ̀kan rẹ̀ bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí i ṣe kì-kì-kì. Ó ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ rẹ̀ sínú ìwé pélébé àlejò, ó ḿu ìjokòó ó sì bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí i wò rá-rà-rá, tìbẹ̀rù tìbẹ̀rù. Gbogbo nǹkan inú ọ́fíìsì àwọn agbẹ́jọ́rò yìí ni ó ní bátànì, bí wọ́n ṣe kí i káàbọ̀; ìkíni rẹ̀ àti bí wọ́n ṣe ń dáhùn ìbéèrè.

English: Good day madam.
Yoruba: Ẹ kú ojúmọ́ ìyá.

English: Here to see the lawyer?
Yoruba: Ẹ fẹ́ rí Agbẹjọ́rò?

English: That's right, please take your seat, you are welcome.
Yoruba: Ó dáa bẹ́ẹ̀, ẹ jọ̀wọ́, ẹ jókòó, ẹ káàbọ̀.

English: Could you fill this slip? O.K. I'll be back right now." the receptionist walked briskly, but noiselessly into an inner office with the visitors" slip, and returned exactly two minutes later.
Yoruba: Ṣe ẹ lè ṣe àkọ́sílẹ̀ yìí? Ó dáa. Mò ńbọ̀ nísìnyí," olùgbàlejò náà rìn kíà láìpariwo lọ inú ọ́fíìsì kan nínú, ó sì padà dé lẹ́yìn ìṣẹ́jú méjì gérégé.

English: "You will please hold on madam, for about five minutes."
Yoruba: "Ẹ máa ní láti dúró ìyá, fún bí ìṣẹ́jú márùn-ún."

English: Labake saw the pictures of the two lawyers running the chambers hanging on the wall. They both wore the typical lawyer's look - unsmiling; stern-looking; brows knitted; lips tensed; uncompromising features and a penetrating gaze- strong enough to make the beholder blush. One of them wore dark glasses and looked familiar to Labake.
Yoruba: Làbákẹ́ rí àwòrán agbẹjọ́rò méjì tí ó darí ọ́fíísì náà tí wọn gbé kọ́ ògiri. Àwọn méjéèjì múra bí i agbẹjọ́rò - láìrẹ́rìn-ín pẹ̀lú ojú líle wọn fa ojú ro ẹnu wọn padé, àwọn àbùdá tí kì í jẹ́kí ènìyàn ṣe àní-àní, àti ìwò àrímáleèlọ ni wọ́n ní tí ó ń mú ẹni yòówù tí ó bá rí wọn gbàgbé ara wọn. Ọ̀kan lára wọn lo ìgò dúdú ojú rẹ̀ sì jọ ojú mímọ̀ sí Làbákẹ́.

English: After exactly five minutes, Labake was ushered into a room where one of the lawyers, Akanni Mustafa was waiting to receive her.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ìsẹ́jú márùn-ún géérégé, wọn pe Làbákẹ́ wọ yàrá kan, tí ọ̀kan ninú àwọn lọ́yà, ìyẹn Àkànní Mústàfá ti ń dúró láti gbà á lálejò.

English: "You are welcome madam."
Yoruba: "Ẹ káàbọ̀ ìyá"

English: "Please pull a chair, we are at your service, what's the problem? Take it easy, take everything easy."
Yoruba: "Ẹ mú àga kan, a wà níbí fún yín, kí ló sẹlẹ̀? Ẹ ṣe jẹ́jẹ́, ẹ ṣe gbogbo ǹkan jẹ́jẹ́."

English: Barrister Mustafa had obviously noticed the anxiety on the face of Labake.
Yoruba: Amòfin Mústàfá ti ṣàkíyèsí hílà-hílo tí ó hàn lójú Làbákẹ́.

English: He was an experienced lawyer who knew how best to put the clients" mind at ease.
Yoruba: Ó jẹ́ agbẹjọ́rò tí ó ní ìrírí tí ó sì mọ bí wọ́n ṣe ń fi ọkàn oníbàárà balẹ̀.

English: Whatever was the magnitude of the problem, he knew that clients would always display fear and anxiety.
Yoruba: Kò síbí ìṣòro náà ṣe lè pọ̀ tó, ó mọ̀ pé àwọn oníbàárà máa ń gbé ìbẹ̀rù àti hílà-hílo wọn sójú.

English: Those who came for criminal cases were usually the most difficult to handle.
Yoruba: Àwọn tí ó bá bá ọ̀rọ̀ ọ̀ràn wá ní wọn máa ń le láti kojú jù.

English: They would relate their experience sobbing, biting their lips, sucking their fingertips, and pulling at the hair.
Yoruba: Wọn á máa sọ ìrírí wọn tẹkúntẹkún, wọn á má a gé ètè ara wọn jẹ, wọn á má fa orí ìka ọwọ́ wọn mú tàbí kí wọn máa fa irun ara wọn.

English: And this always made it difficult, if not impossible, to get details immediately.
Yoruba: Àwọn èyí sì má a ń jẹ́ kí ó le tàbí, kí ó má ṣe é ṣe láti rí àlàyé kíkún gbà lẹ́nu wọn.

English: For them, the fact-finding investigation had to be conducted very tactfully.
Yoruba: Fún irú wọn, ìwádìí òtítọ́ ní láti wáyé pẹ̀lú ọgbọ́n ẹ̀wẹ́.

English: Otherwise, there would be loop-holes created here and there to the advantage of the opposing camp.
Yoruba: Láìjẹ́ bẹ́ẹ̀ àwọn ìhò a pọ̀ fún àǹfààní àwọn ọ̀tá láti rí wọ̀.

English: But those who came for civil cases were milder and easier to handle.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn tí wọn bá bá ẹjọ́ abẹ́lé wá máa ń rọrùn láti gbámú.

English: With occasional expressions of griefs, clients in this category would shout their innocence and speak a large part of truth - if not the whole truth.
Yoruba: Wọn a máa fi ẹ̀dùn ọkàn wọn hàn lẹ́ẹ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan oníbàárà ní abẹ́ ọ̀wọ́ yìí máa ń fọnrere àìmọ́wọ mẹsẹ̀ wọn, wọ́n sì máa ń sọ púpọ̀ òótọ́ ọ̀rọ̀ wọn ìyẹn tí kì í báá ṣe òótọ́ pọ́nbélé.

English: And if you cross-examined them twenty times they would repeat the same account with just a little, or no contradiction at all.
Yoruba: Bí ènìyàn bá sì ṣàgbéyẹ̀wò nǹkan tí wọn bá sọ nígbà ogún, nǹkan kan náà ni ẹni náà á gbọ́ lẹ́nu wọn pẹ̀lú ìyàtọ̀ bín-ín-tín tàbí kí ó má sì ìyàtọ̀ kankan rárá.

English: Lawyer Mustafa put Labake in the second category. He was right.
Yoruba: Irú ọwọ́ yìí ni agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá fi Làbákẹ́ sí. Ó sì tọ̀nà bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: Breathlessly, Labake related her experience in her matrimonial home, she traced the story of her happy love affair with Alamu right from the time they were in England through to the time they arrived in Nigeria for the marriage, which was celebrated with pomp and peageantry.
Yoruba: Láísìnmi, Làbákẹ́ ròyìn gbogbo ìrírí rẹ̀ nílé ọkọ rẹ̀, ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ ìtàn ìfẹ́ rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú Àlàmú láti ìbẹ̀rẹ̀, nígbà tí wọn wà nílùú Englandi títí di ìgbà tí wọ́n fi dé orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà fún ìgbéyàwó tí wọ́n ṣe táyé gbọ́ tọ́run mọ̀.

English: Hopes were high for a great future as Alamu secured the lucrative job of an Accountant in the reputable Bajoks Company Limited and their child, Tinu, arrived to add to their joy.
Yoruba: Ìrètí wọn fún ọjọ́ iwájú wọn ga bí Àlàmú ṣe rísẹ́ asírò-ọ̀rọ̀ sílé iṣẹ́ Bajoks tó gbajúmọ̀, àti ọmọ wọn Tinú tó dé láti wá dákún ayọ̀ wọn.

English: From then on, fate struck a devastating blow and the matrimonial life.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ìgbà náà ní ìjì bẹ̀rẹ̀ si í jà tí ọkọ̀ ìgbéyàwó wọn bẹ̀rẹ̀ si í kọsẹ̀.

English: Each the woeful event came vividly to her mind, and with the force and reality of a picture-strip from a film projector.
Yoruba: Gbogbo ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà ń wá sí i lọ́kàn kedere bí ìgbà tí ó bá sẹ̀sẹ̀ ń sẹlẹ̀.

English: She related the story of her husband's deterioration and his eccentric habits at home.
Yoruba: Ó sọ ìtàn ìfàsẹ́yìn ọkọ rẹ̀ àti àwọn ìṣe aágà nná tí ó ń ṣe nílé.

English: Her eyes welled up in tears when she came to the role her old mother-in-law was playing in the whole affair.
Yoruba: Ojú rẹ̀ kúnfún omijé nígbà tí ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ̀ débi ipa tí ìyá ọkọ rẹ̀ ń kó nínú gbogbo ọ̀rọ̀ náà.

English: That was to her, the final straw breaking the camels back.
Yoruba: Sí i ìyẹn ni àjẹǹjẹtán ọ̀rọ̀ náà.

English: Labake did not know how best to knit the events together to make a good case for a divorce suit.
Yoruba: Làbákẹ́ ò mọ ònà tí ó dára jù láti so gbogbo ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà pọ̀ láti lè fi ṣe ẹjọ́ ìkọ̀sílẹ̀ gidi.

English: By the time she'd finished her story, she'd become so completely overcome, she felt so hot all over the body even though the air-conditioner was switched to its maximum in the lawyer's office.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí ó máa fi parí ìtàn rẹ̀, ó dàbí i pé wọ́n ti borí, ọ̀rọ̀ náà ti gbọ̀n-ọ́n, ooru mú un ní gbogbo ara, bí ó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé ẹ̀rọ amúlétutù wà ní títàn dé góńgó nínú ọ́fíísì agbẹjọ́rò náà.

English: Alright... Alright madam. Take it easy madam, we have a case ... a good case.
Yoruba: Ó dáa ... Ó dáa ìyáàfin, ẹ ṣe jẹ́jẹ́ ìyáàfin, à ti lẹ́jọ́ ... ẹjọ́ tó dára.

English: We have good grounds to start a divorce suit.
Yoruba: A sì ti ní ìpìlẹ̀ tó dára láti bẹ̀rẹ̀ ẹjọ́ ìkọ̀sílẹ̀.

English: Lawyer Mustafa pressed a button and it was then that Labake saw, for the first time that all what she said had been tape-recorded.
Yoruba: Agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá tẹ bọ́tìnì kan, ìgbà náà ni Làbákẹ́ sẹ̀sẹ̀ rí i pé gbogbo nǹkan tí òun sọ ni wọ́n ti gbà sílẹ̀.

English: That, of course, did not matter much to her it was the way of the lawyers.
Yoruba: Gbogbo èyí kò kúkú kàn án, ọ̀nà àwọn agbẹjọ́rò nìyẹn.

English: All she wanted was a quick nullification of the marriage contract. No more no less. And she had every confidence in his lawer whom everybody in town knew for his fearlessness and competence in interpreting the law.
Yoruba: Gbogbo nǹkan tí ó ń fẹ́ ni ìtúká ìgbéyàwó náà ní kíákíá. Kò fẹ́ nǹkan mìíràn lẹ́yìn ìyẹn. Ó sì ní ìgbàgbọ́ nínú agbẹjọ́rò tí gbogbo ènìyàn ìgboro mọ̀ nígbòro fún àìníbẹ̀rù rẹ̀ àti ìgbójú rẹ̀ nínú títúmọ̀ òfin.

English: Lawyer Mustafa and his partner had the reputation of handling seemingly hopeless cases, holding the court spellbound, confusing the opponents with incontrovertible evidence.
Yoruba: Agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá àti ẹnìkejì rẹ̀ ní orúkọ nípa kíkápá ẹjọ́ tí a rò pé kò nírètí mọ́ nípa lílo ẹ̀rí tó yèkoro láti ka kóòtù ní ẹ̀jafúú àti láti dà òpó àwọn alátakò rú pẹ̀lú ẹ̀rí tó dájú.

English: "We have a good case madam," he repeated, "No need o worry."
Yoruba: "A ní ẹjọ́ tó dára ìyáàfin," ó tún un sọ, "Ẹ kò nílò láti dààmú."

English: We are going to file a divorce suit on five grounds: drunkenness, wickedness, dereliction of duty, neglect of responsibility and total disrespect for thee sacred oath of the Marriage Act on the part of your husband."
Yoruba: A máa fi ẹ̀sùn yìí kàn lórí ẹ̀sùn márùn-ún yìí; ọtí àmupara, ìwà ìkà, àìka isẹ́-ẹni sí, fífi ojúṣe-ẹni sílẹ̀ àti àìbọ̀wọ̀ fún ìgbéyàwó fún ọkọ yín.

English: Lawyer Mustafa finished, chuckling confidently.
Yoruba: Agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá parí ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ̀ ó sì rẹ́rìn-ín pẹ̀lú ìgboyà.

English: Lawyer Mustafa asked Labake a few other minor questions about the home and requested her to submit to them at the chambers, her marriage certificate and wedding ring for inspection - also their wedding album.
Yoruba: Agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá bí Làbákẹ́ ní àwọn ìbéèrè kéékèèké mìíràn nípa ilé, ó sì sọ fún un pé kí ó mú àwọn ìwé-ẹ̀rí àti òrùka ìgbéyàwó wá fún ìtọpinpin àti ìwé àkojọpọ̀àwòrán ìgbéyàwó wọn náà.

English: After that, they would sit down, and determine what her bill would be - how much she would pay, and the rest.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn èyí ni wọ́n á jòkòó, wọn á sì wo iye owó tí yóò san, owó iṣẹ́ rẹ̀ àti àwọn nǹkan yòókù.

English: "It's a pity madam," Lawyer Mustafa said, "my partner is out.
Yoruba: "Ó ṣeni láàánú ìyá," Agbejọ́rò Mústàfá ń bá ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ̀ bọ̀, "Ẹnìkejì mi jáde."

English: You will have the opportunity of meeting him when next you come.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ ẹ́ ní àǹfààní láti mọ̀ ọ́n nígbà tí ẹ bá tún wá.

English: We are always together.... You know, putting heads together to crack the nut of stubborn cases. Two heads are better than one, as people say.
Yoruba: A jọ máa ń wà pọ̀ ni .... Ṣé ẹ mọ̀, kí a foríkorí láti fọ agbọ̀n ẹjọ́ tó bá yi. Orí méjì sàn ju ọ̀kan bí àwọn ènìyàn ṣe máa ń sọ.

English: I'll brief him fully about your suit... in case my plan to travel abroad next week materializes, he'll take over your case.
Yoruba: Máa sọ ọ̀rọ̀ ẹjọ́ yín fún un... aìíbaàámọ̀ èrò mi láti lọ sí ìlú ọba lè wá sí ìmúsẹ lọ́sẹ̀ tó ń bọ̀, òun ni yóò bá a yín máa bá ẹjọ́ náà lọ.

English: We are one and the same, no problem. Labake smiled, the battle was, indeed, half-won. With these two sharp lawyers battling it out on her behalf in court, she had nothing to fear, she was going to defeat Alamu hands down.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kanṣoṣo ni wá, nǹkankan náà sì ní wá pẹ́lù, kò sí ìṣòro. Làbákẹ́ rẹ́rìn-ín músẹ́, ó ti ja ogun náà ní àjàyè dé ìdajì. Pẹ̀lú ìrànwọ́ àwọn agbejọ́rò tó múnádoko méjì yìí nílé ẹjọ́, kò ní nǹkankan láti bẹ̀rù, yóò borí Àlàmú délẹ̀.

English: When finally Labake rose to go, her countenance had brightened. Her heart had stopped beating that confused rhythm. And what she heard finally from Lawyer Mustafa raised her spirit and cheered her heart. It was like tonic to a troubled heart.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí Làbákẹ́ jàjà dìde láti máa lọ, ojú rẹ̀ ti yàtọ̀. Ọkàn rẹ̀ ti ṣíwọ́ lílù kì-kì-kì. Òhun tí ó sì gbọ́ lẹ́nu Agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá gbẹ̀yìn gbé ẹ̀mí rẹ̀ sókè, ó sì dá ọkàn rẹ̀ lárayá. Ó dàbí i òògùn ẹ̀jẹ̀ sí ọkàn tí ó ti pòrúurù.

English: "No problem about the little child - your child, Lawyer Mustafa assured, she will be adequately catered for in the suit, we know how to do that," the Lawyer calmed her again.
Yoruba: "Kò sí ìṣòro nípa ti ọmọ kékeré yẹn-ọmọ yín, amáa ṣètọ́jú tirẹ̀ nínú ẹjọ́ náà, a mọ bí a ṣe máa ṣe é," Agbẹjọ́rò tún fi ọkàn rẹ̀ balẹ̀.

English: Labake walked out of the lawyer's office smiling at the courteous receptionist.
Yoruba: Làbákẹ́ rìn jáde nínú ọ́fíisì agbẹjọ́rò náà pẹ̀lú ẹ̀rín músẹ́ sí olùgbàlejò ọlọ́yàyà náà.

English: Lawyer Mustafa's eyes followed his prospective client out.
Yoruba: Ojú Agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá tẹ̀lé oníbàárà rẹ̀ jáde.

English: What a thoroughly disillusioned that young lady she was.
Yoruba: Irú arábìnrin aláìlẹ́tàn tí ó jẹ́.

English: A lady who had seen the troubles of marraige just once and thinks it would crush her. The problem with her was the problem with thousands of other young housewives in town.
Yoruba: Obìnrin tí ó ti rí wàhálà ìgbéyàwó ní ẹ̀ẹ̀kan ṣoṣo, ti ó wá ń rò ó pé ọ̀runfúnrarẹ fẹ́ wó pa á. Ìṣòro tí ó ní yìí náà ní ìṣòro tí ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún àwọn ìyàwó-ilé kéé-kèè-ké mìíràn ń ní nígboro.

English: The women would have sleepless nights over small matrimonial matters.
Yoruba: Àwọn obìnrin náà ń ṣe àìsùn lóru lórí ọ̀rọ̀ tí ò tó nǹkan nínú ìgbéyàwó.

English: They would lament and curse the day they were married!
Yoruba: Wọn á rojọ́, wọn à sì gégùn-ún fún ọjọ́ tí wọn ṣe ìsopọ̀ tọkọtaya!

English: They would swear the end had come.
Yoruba: Wọn á búra pé òpin ti dé.

English: They would threaten to take poison, and what they fret so much about, in most cases, are matters that could be amicably settled out of court by their respective parents at home.
Yoruba: Wọn á halẹ̀ láti gbé májèlé jẹ, àwọn nǹkan tí ó ń bí wọn nínú lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà kìí tó nǹkan, irú àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀ ṣe é yanjú nílé pẹ̀lú àwọn òbí wọn láìdélé ẹjọ́.

English: It was either that the husband stayed in the office doing over-time work with the lady secretary for company; that would not eat well at home - indicating that he'd satisfied himself somewhere outside; that he sleeps off immediately after dinner and would not wake up till early the following morning; that he would talk in his sleep about some secret lover or that the husband no longer placed his fat salary at the disposal of members of the household; that he was tied to the apron strings of his parents, neglecting her - the lady of the house and so forth.
Yoruba: Ó lè jẹ́ pé ọkọ pẹ́ níbisẹ́ tí ó ń ṣe àṣekún iṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú akọ̀we rẹ̀ obìnrin; tí ò sì jẹun dáadáa nílé, ìyẹn ń túmọ̀ sí pé ó tí tẹ ara rẹ̀ lọ́rùn níbìkan ni; bí ó bá sùn ní kété tó jẹun alẹ́ tí ò sì jí títí tí ilẹ̀ ọjọ́ kejì fi mọ́; tàbí ó sọ̀rọ̀ olólùfẹ́ ìkọ̀kọ̀ láti ojú oorun tàbí pé ọkọ ò gbé owó oṣù rẹ̀ lé bùkátà àwọn ara ilé mọ̀ tàbí pé ó sọ ara rẹ̀ mọ́ àwọn òbí rẹ̀ jú, tí ó sì gbójúfò òun dá - ìyẹn ìyàwó ilé àti àwọn ìdí bẹ́è bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ.

English: Lawyer Mustafa watched Labake walk away. He was full of pity for her.
Yoruba: Agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá wo Làbákẹ́ bí ó ṣe ń rìn lọ, tí àánú rẹ̀ sì ń ṣe é.

English: If only woman would learn to endure and men would learn to be patient; if only couples would learn to talk over their grievances with mutual love and respect, and laugh over their mistakes and failures, surely, bitterness would find no place in their homes and the question of going to court to settle scores would be entirely out of it. But then, that would put lawyers out of business.
Yoruba: Bí àwọn obìnrin bá lè kọ́ bí a ṣe ń rọ́jú, kí àwọn ọkùnrin náà kọ́ bí a ṣe ń ní sùúrù; bí àwọn tokọtaya bá lè kọ́ bí á ṣe ń sọ̀rọ̀ lórí ìbànújẹ́ wọn pẹ̀lú àjọpín ìfẹ́ àti ìbọ̀wọ̀ kí wọ́n sì rẹ́rìn-ín lórí gbogbo àṣìṣe àti ìkùnà wọn, dájúdájú ìkorò ò ní ráyè nínú ilé wọn, kò sì ní sí ìdí láti gbẹ́jọ́ wọn délé ẹjọ́ kí wọn tó parí ẹ̀. Ṣùgbọ́n báyẹn, àwọn agbẹjọ́rò ò ní rí isẹ́ ṣe.

English: Lawyer Mustafa knew it was good that he had agreed to help Labake prosecute the case.
Yoruba: Agbẹjọ́rò Mústàfá mọ̀ pé ó dára bí òun ṣe gbà láti bá Làbákẹ́ ṣe ẹjọ́ náà.

English: Labake was satisfied, she arrived back at home a satisfied woman.
Yoruba: Ó tẹ́ Làbákẹ́ lọ́rùn, ó délé padà bí obìnrin tí ó ní ìtẹ̀lọ́rùn.

English: But with one resolution: that she would henceforth meet force with force.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n pẹ̀lú ìpinnu kan nipé òun a máa gbé ipá wojú ipá ni.

English: If Alamu was dumb, she too would seal her own lips completely.
Yoruba: Bí Àlàmú bá ya odi, òun náà a se ètè tirẹ̀ pátápátá.

English: If he shouted at her, she too would yell back at him.
Yoruba: Bí ó bá pariwo mọ́ ọn, òun náà á pariwo padà.

English: If Alamu laughed out to her, the usual way - like a mad man, she too would open her mouth wide and trumpet her laughter - so loud it would make Alamu himself tremble!
Yoruba: Bí Àlàmú bá rẹ́rìn-ín aláriwo sí i bí ó ṣe máa ń rín in bí i wèrè, òun náà á lánu tirẹ̀ fẹ̀, á sì rín ẹ̀rín aláriwo tirẹ̀ padà, ariwo rẹ̀ á pọ̀ tó bẹ́ẹ̀ tí Àlàmú fúnrarẹ á gbọ̀n rìrì!

English: Henceforth, it was going to be the tramp facing the lunatic inside a mad house in open combat! Two forces.
Yoruba: Láti ìsìnyí lọ, ọ̀rọ̀ wọn á di ti alárìnkiri tí ó kọjúmọ́ asínwín nílé wèrè, ní ìjàkadì gbangba! Agbára ipá méjì.

English: Then the inevitable explosion which would for ever separate them.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn náà ni ti ariwo tí ò ṣe é sá fún tí yóò tú wọn ká títí láé.

English: The voice of Tinu came to Labake from the backyard of their flat - mocking her or so it seemed.
Yoruba: Ohùn Tinú wá sí etí Làbákẹ́ láti ẹ̀hìnkùlé ilé wọn - bí ìgbà tí ó bá ń ṣe yẹ̀yẹ́ ní o jọ́.

English: "Tata - Tatata - Papapa Papa - Papapa." The little girl staggered towards the sitting room and saw her mother. Then she changed her mind.
Yoruba: "Tata-tatata - bababa-baba-bababa," ọmọ náà ta gbọ̀n-ọ́n gbọ̀n-ọ́n lọ́nà yàrá ìgbafẹ́, ó sì rí ìyá rẹ̀. Lẹ́yìn náà ní ó yí ọkàn padà.

English: "Mama - ma ma ma ma - mama - mamama."
Yoruba: "Màmá-ma ma ma -màmá-mamama"

English: Labake smiled, what a sharp quick-witted child she was.
Yoruba: Làbákẹ́ rẹ́rìn-ín músẹ́, irú ọmọ tó gbọ́n wo rè é.

English: If she had the gift of language, she would have long gone to deliver the message she sent her to her daddy.
Yoruba: Bí ó bá jẹ́ pé ó ni ẹ̀bùn èdè ni, á tí jíṣẹ́ tí ó rán sí bàbá rẹ̀ tipẹ́tipẹ́.

English: A very sharp, very inquisitive little girl, she would grow up in future with questions on her smart lips.
Yoruba: Ọmọ tí ó dá ṣáṣá , tí ó gbọ́n, bí ó bá dàgbà lọ́jọ́ iwájú ìbéèrè ákún ẹnu rẹ̀.

English: She would want to know why she was the victim of a broken home. Yes... She had right to know.
Yoruba: Á fẹ́ mọ̀ ìdí tí ó fi jẹ́ pé ilé tí ó túká ni òun ti wá. Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni... ó ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti mọ̀.

English: Labake knew it would be imperative to satisfy Tinu with an explanation.
Yoruba: Làbákẹ́ mọ̀ pé dandan ni kí òun fi àlàyé tẹ́ Tinú lọ́rùn.

English: There was the need for her, henceforth, to start keeping a diary of the daily events at home.
Yoruba: Ó nílò láti ní ìwé ìjẹ́rìí-ẹni tí yóò máa kọ ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ojoojúmọ́ inú ilé náà sí.

English: This diary she would show Tinu in future.
Yoruba: Ìwé yìí ni á fi han Tinú lọ́jọ́ iwájú.

English: And the poor girl, no doubt, would read it with tears in her eyes.
Yoruba: Ọmọbìnrin aláìsẹ̀, náàá kàá pẹ̀lú omijé lójú láìsí àní-àní.

English: Her father's beer and how he vomitted on her, how he pushed her, how he kicked little Tinu herself, the poor girl screaming, tumbling, bruising her lips and the gum of her newly-formed teeth.
Yoruba: Ọtí àmupara bàbá rẹ̀ - bí ó ṣe bì sí i lára tí ó sì tì í, ó ta á nípàá, tí ọmọ náà ń han, tí ó ń yíràá nílẹ̀ tí ó ṣèṣe létè àti èrìgì eyín tuntun rẹ̀ lọ́jọ kan.

English: Her father's madness and neglect, shirking all the responsibilities of a father and husband, his uproarious laughter and the detestable habit of keeping late hours outside.
Yoruba: Wèrè àti ìtàdanù bàbá rẹ̀, tí ó ń gbọn ẹ̀tọ́ rẹ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bí i bàbá àti ọkọ dànù, ẹ̀rín aláriwo rẹ̀, àti wíwọlé lóru rẹ̀ bí ọrọ̀.

English: All these things combining to push her to seek divorce, not to talk of the constant disgrace and embarrasment from Mama and the neighbours...
Yoruba: Gbogbo èyí ló tì í láti sẹjọ́ ìkọ̀sílẹ̀, kí á tó wá sọ ti àbùkù ti màmá fi ń kàn án àti ìdààmú láti ọwọ́ màmá àti àwọn ará àdúgbò...

English: Labake was right. The neighbours' attitude had started becoming more and more intolerable. Only last night Labake heard her neighbours talking to her again in the usual way; but this time in a tone that was both sarcastic and contemptuous.
Yoruba: Òtítọ́ ni Làbákẹ́ sọ. Ìṣesí àwọn ará àdúgbò rẹ̀ kò ṣe é gbà sára rárá. Alẹ́ àná nàá ni Làbákẹ́ gbọ́ tí àwọn ará àdúgbò rẹ̀ tún ń bá a wí bí wọn ṣe máa ń sọ; Ṣùgbọ́n tọ̀tẹ̀ yìí ń pẹ̀gàn ni.

English: He's not only mad. She is mad too,
Yoruba: Ọkọ nìkan kọ́ ló ya wèrè, Ìyàwó náà ya wèrè,

English: Two mad people. Mad home.
Yoruba: Àwọn wèrè méjì . Ilé wèrè.

English: She pretends not to hear us, what is she waiting for really? Tell us, mad woman...
Yoruba: Ó ń díbọ́n bí ìgbà tí kò gbọ́ wa, kí ló ń dúró dè, lóòótọ́? Sọ fún wa, wèrè obìnrin...

English: They did not face her directly to talk. How then was she going to defend herself?
Yoruba: Wọn kò kọjúsí i tààrà láti sọ̀rọ̀. Báwo ni yóò ṣe wá gbèjà ara rẹ̀?

English: What a tantalising situation! A case of the prosecutor dragging the accused to court to pronounce judgment without a trial.
Yoruba: Irú ipò ìyọnilẹ́nu wò rè é! Ọ̀rọ̀ wá di ti olùpéjọ́ ti ó ń wọ àfẹ̀sùnkàn lọ sí ilé ẹjọ́ láti dájọ́ láìsí ìpèléjọ́.

English: Well, the whole world was apparently against her - Mama, Alamu, the neighbours and all.
Yoruba: Gbogbo ayé ni wọn ti kẹ̀yìn si - Màmá, Àlàmú, àwọn ará àdúgbò àti gbogbo ènìyàn.

English: So, nobody was going to stop her from pursuing the divorce suit to its logical conclusion.
Yoruba: Fún ìdí èyí, kò sí ẹnìkan tí yóò díi lọ́wọ́ láti pe ẹjọ́ ìkọ̀sílẹ̀ náà títí dé òpin.

English: If in future Tinu asked her questions, she too would have questions to ask Tinu in return, she would ask if Tinu, as a woman could have put up with such a situation and not seek divorce.
Yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ iwájú, bí Tinú bá bi í ní ìbèérè, òun náà á ní ìbèérè láti bi Tinú padà, á bèrè bí Tinú náà bá lè gba irú rẹ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bí obìnrin, kí ó máa bèèr̀e fún ìkọ́sílẹ̀.

English: Alamu's head was up in the air.
Yoruba: Orí Àlàmú wà lókè.

English: He kept his eyes on the sitting room ceiling as he hurried out of the house clutching two files.
Yoruba: Ó tẹjúmọ́ òkè àjà yàrá ìgbafẹ́ wọn bí ó ṣe ń kánjú kúrò nínú ilé tí ó sì mú ìwé méjì pọ.

English: Labake too was hastening out of the kitchen. Husband and wife brushed past each other, chest to chest.
Yoruba: Làbákẹ́ jáde láti ilé ìdáná. Ọkọ àti ìyàwó bá kọlu ara wọn, ní ìdàyà kọ àyà.

English: The two files Alamu was holding dropped from his hand. And the empty kettle Labake was holding also fell from her hand.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìwé méjì tí Àlàmú kó dání jábọ́ lọ́wọ́ rẹ̀. Bẹ́ẹ̀ sì ni kẹ́tùlù tí Làbákẹ́ gbé dání náà jábọ́ lọ́wọ́ rẹ̀.

English: It was not easy to apportion blame.
Yoruba: Kò rọrùn láti dá ẹnìkan lẹ́bi.

English: If Alamu had his eyes fixed up on the ceiling, Labake had hers probing down into the floor of the room.
Yoruba: Bí ó bá jẹ́ pé Àlàmú ń tẹjú mọ́ òkè àjà ni, Làbákẹ́ náà tẹjú tirẹ̀ mọ ilẹ̀ ni bí ó ṣe ń rìn.

English: For some seconds, they stood gazing at each other, questioning each other with a bad look.
Yoruba: Fún bí i ìṣẹ́jú àáyá díẹ̀, wọ́n dúró ń wojú ara wọn, wọ́n ń fi ojú burúkú bi ara wọn léèrè.

English: Alamu did not utter a word.
Yoruba: Àlàmú kò lanu sọ nǹkankan.

English: Labake too did not open her lips.
Yoruba: Làbákẹ́ náà ò sì la ẹnu rẹ̀.

English: Silently, Alamu bent down and picked up his files.
Yoruba: Ní ìdákẹ́rọ́rọ́ ni Àlàmú bẹ̀rẹ̀ mọ́lẹ̀ tí ó sì kó ìwé rẹ̀.

English: Labake too quietly stooped to pick her kettle ... And the two of them went their separate ways!
Yoruba: Làbákẹ́ náà bẹ̀rẹ̀ gbé kẹ́tùlù nílẹ̀... Oníkálukú sì bá ọ̀nà tirẹ̀ lọ!

English: To hell with this man! This terrible mad man
Yoruba: Kò ní dá a fún ọkùnrin yìí! Ọmọkùnrin wèrè burúkú yìí.

English: Labake seemed to be whispering to herself.
Yoruba: Ó fẹ jọ wí pé Làbákẹ́ ń sọ èyí sí ara rẹ̀ ní kẹ́lẹ́kélẹ́.

English: Force with force! Nothing short of that! In a few days time, Alamu would get the court summons.
Yoruba: Ipá pẹ̀lú ipá ni! Kò sí ohun mìíràn lẹ́yiǹ ìyẹn! Tí a bá máa fì rí ọjọ́ mélòó kan, Àlàmú á gba ìpèlẹ́jọ́ ilé ẹjọ́.

English: His eyes would turn red and his lips would tremble like the leaves on the tree.
Yoruba: Ojú rẹ̀ á pọ́n, ètè rẹ̀ á sì gbọ̀n bí i ewé orí igi.

English: The summons would wake up all the ghosts inside his crazy head and send him off to the streets blaring the wild meaningless song of a thoroughly mad man.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìpèlẹ́jọ́ yẹn á jí gbogbo iwin inú orí ẹ̀ sílẹ̀, á sì rán an sí òpópónà káàkiri, á máa kígbe orin ẹhànnà aláìnítumọ̀ rẹ̀ kíkan kíkan tí ó jọ ti wèrè pọ́ńbélé.

English: Of course, his mother would be hot on his heels on the streets shouting the eccentric chorus! That was his own palaver... And the palaver of this old witch he called his mother.
Yoruba: Dájúdájú ẹsẹ̀ ìyà rẹ̀ a gbóná lórí òpópónà, tí yóò máa pariwo orin ayírí! Wàhálà tirẹ̀ niyẹn... àti wàhálà àjẹ́ àgbà tí ó pè ní ìyá rẹ̀.

English: Labake watched, amused, each time Alamu cast his hungry look at the dining room table. He would, for some time gaze intently at the dining table at the usual meal times only to see empty water bottles, cups turned upside down and the unwashed plates piled up with flies at strategic positions, keeping vigilant watch!
Yoruba: Làbákẹ́ ń wò pẹ̀lú ìyanú, nígbàkigbà tí Àlàmú bá wo tábìlì yàrá ìjẹun tebi-tebi. A tẹjú mọ́ tábìlì náà ní às̀ikò tí ó yẹ kí oúnjẹ délẹ̀, Ṣùgbọ́n kòròfo ìgò omi, ife tí wọ́n dojú ẹ̀ kọlẹ̀ àti àwọn abọ́ ìdọ̀tí tí wọ́n tò jọ pẹ̀lú esinsin nípò wọn, tí wọn ń ṣisẹ́ ẹ̀sọ́!

English: Labake had no explanation to give anybody anymore for her action.
Yoruba: Kò sí àlàyé tí Làbákẹ́ fẹ́ ṣe fún ẹnikẹni lórí ìṣe rẹ̀.

English: She was no longer accountable to anybody.
Yoruba: Kò lè jábọ̀ fún ẹnikẹ́ni mọ́.

English: She was no longer the lady of the house. She did not see herself as such anymore.
Yoruba: Òun kọ́ ni ìyá-ilé mọ́, kò sì rí ara rẹ̀ bí i ọ̀kan mọ́.

English: The lady of the house was the woman in perfect control of the affairs of the home.
Yoruba: Ìyá-ilé ní obìnrin tí gbogbo ìsẹ̀lẹ̀ ilé máa ń wà ní ìkápá rẹ̀.

English: The woman in love with her husband and the woman whom the husband admired in turn.
Yoruba: Obìnrin tí ó nífẹ̀ẹ́ ọkọ rẹ̀, tí ọkọ rẹ̀ sì nífẹ̀ẹ́.

English: The woman in the good books of the relatives of the husband.
Yoruba: Obìnrin tí ó ní àkọ́sílẹ̀ rere lọ́dọ̀ àwọn ẹbí ọkọ rẹ̀ fún.

English: So, Labake was not qualified.
Yoruba: Ìdí èyí, Làbákẹ́ kò kún ojú òsùnwọ̀n.

English: Now she was just a mere tenant in Alamu's house.
Yoruba: Ayálégbé lásán ni nílé Àlàmú báyìí.

English: Local radio station in Russia cancels interview with LGBT activists after threats to editor
Yoruba: Ilé-iṣẹ́ Agbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Ìbílẹ̀ Fagilé Ìfọ̀rọ̀wọ́rọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn ajìjàǹgbara LGBT lẹ́yìn ìhalẹ̀mọ́ sí olóòtú

English: Activists in Madrid protest LGBT rights violations in Russia
Yoruba: Àwọn ajìjàǹgbara ní Madrid fi ẹ̀hónú hàn lórí ìrúfin ẹ̀tọ́ LGBT ní Russia

English: Echo of Moscow in Yaroslavl, a local affiliate of Echo of Moscow, Russia's oldest independent radio network, cancelled an interview with LGBT activists after receiving homophobic threats, the station's editor Lyudmila Shabuyeva said in a Facebook post:
Yoruba: Ilé-iṣẹ́ Echo ti Moscow ní Yaroslavl tí ó jẹ́ ẹ̀ka ilé-iṣẹ́ Agbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Echo ti Moscow ìsopọ̀ tí ó ti dá dúró fún ìgbà pípẹ́ ní Russia fagi lé ìfọ̀rọ̀wọ́rọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn ajìjàǹgbara LGBT lẹ́yìn tí wọ́n gba ìhalẹ̀ láti ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn tí ó kórìíra-ìbálòpọ̀-láàárín-akọ-àti-akọ, olóòtú ilé-iṣẹ́ náà Lyudmila Shabuyeva sọ̀rọ̀ nínú àkọsílẹ̀ Facebook kan:

English: Translation Original Quote
Yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

English: Yesterday we received threats against our guests and ourselves if we proceed with our talk show about LGBT.
Yoruba: Ní àná, a gba ìhàlẹ̀ kan tí ó ń lérí mọ́ àwa àti àwọn àlejòo wa tí a bá tẹ̀síwajú pẹ̀lú ètò ìfọ̀rọ̀wọ́rọ̀ọ wa nípa LGBT.

English: I'm cancelling the show.
Yoruba: Mò ń fagi lé ètò náà.

English: According to independent newspaper Novaya Gazeta, the show featuring Yaroslavl's LGBT activists was scheduled to air in the early morning of Wednesday, January 23.
Yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìwé ìròyìn tí ò sí ní abẹ́ ìṣàkóso ìjọba Novaya Gazeta ti ṣe sọ, ó yẹ kí ètò náà tí yóò ṣe àfihàn àwọn ajìjàǹgbara LGBT ní Yaroslavl wáyé ní òwúrọ̀ Ọjọ́rú 23, ní oṣù Ṣẹẹrẹ.

English: The same activists had recently picketed the town's main square to protest against the persecution of gay people in Russia, notably in the republic of Chechnya.
Yoruba: Àwọn ajìjàǹgbara yìí kan náà ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ fi ẹ̀hónú hàn ní gbàgede ìlú láti tako ìfìyàjẹ àwọn aṣe-ìbálòpọ̀-akọ-àti-akọ ní Russia, pàápàá jùlọ ní orílẹ̀ Chechnya.

English: The station invited them to be interviewed about the protest and their experience of being openly gay in provincial Russia.
Yoruba: Ilé-iṣẹ́ agbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ náà pè wọ́n láti fi ọ̀rọ̀ wá wọn lẹ́nu wò nípa ìfẹ̀hónúhàn àti ìrírí wọn fún jíjáde sí gbangba gẹ́gẹ́ bíi aṣe-ìbálòpọ̀-akọ-àti-akọ ní ẹ̀ka-ìlúu Russia.

English: Shabuyeva's initial announcement of the show attracted a torrent of homophobic abuse in the comments, including some from local officials, but that didn't put her off, she told Novaya Gazeta.
Yoruba: Ìkéde Shebuyeva àkọ́kọ́ nípa ètò náà fa ẹgbẹlẹmùkù èébú ìkórìíra-ìbálòpọ̀-láàárín-akọ́-àti-akọ nínú àwọn èsì, tí èsì sì wá láti ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ọba kan bákan náà, ṣùgbọ́n ìyẹn ò mú ọkàn-an rẹ̀ kúrò, ó sọ fún Novaya Gazeta.

English: However, late in the night before the show, Shabuyeva says, a stranger called her on the phone from an unidentified number and told her that if she were to proceed with the scheduled programming, her guests would be met outside the studio with baseball bats.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ní alẹ́ ọjọ́ tí ètò náà ku ọ̀la, Shabuyeva sọ̀rọ̀ pé òun gba ìpè àjèjì láti orí òpó ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ kan tí kò ṣe é dámọ̀, ẹni náà sì sọ fún òun pé bí òun bá tẹ̀síwajú pẹ̀lú ètò náà bí ó ṣe ti pinnu, wọ́n máa fi igi ìgbábọ́ọ̀lù-afọwọ́jù pàdé àwọn àlejò rẹ ní ìta ilé-iṣẹ́ náà.

English: She could also face problems, the anonymous caller threatened.
Yoruba: Òun náà sì lè kojúu wàhálà, onípè àjèjì náà léríléka.

English: Fearing for her guests" safety, Shabuyeva cancelled the show and replaced it with another programming.
Yoruba: Nítorí ìbẹ̀rù fún ààbò àwọn àlejòo rẹ̀, Shabuyeva fagilé ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò náà tí ó sì fi ètò mìíràn rọ́pòo rẹ̀.

English: The picket on Yaroslavl's main square was part of a national campaign #saveLGBTinRussia aimed at raising awareness about the brutal persecution of gay people in the republic of Chechnya.
Yoruba: Ìfẹ̀hónúhàn tí ó wáyé ní gbàgede ìlú wà lára ìkéde gbogboògbò #saveLGBTinRussia tí wọ́n fi ń polongo ìyà tí ó rorò tí wọ́n fi ń jẹ àwọn ènìyàn aṣe-ìbálòpọ̀-akọ-àti-akọ ní orílẹ̀ Chechnya.

English: Similar pickets and rallies were held in other Russian cities.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìwọ́de àti ìfẹ̀hónúhàn irú èyí wáyé ní àwọn ìlú mìíràn ní Russia.

English: The Motherland Calls on her children (the citizens) to fight xenophobia and repressions in modern Russia.
Yoruba: Ìlú ń ké pe àwọn ọmọ rẹ̀ (àwọn ọmọ ìlú) láti dojú ìjà kọ ìwà elẹ́yàmẹyà àti ìtẹ̀mọ́lẹ̀ ní Russia òde-òní.

English: Let her call awaken you!
Yoruba: Jẹ́ kí ìpèe rẹ̀ ta ọ́ jí!

English: [the sign says: RUSSIA'S DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE COULD FIND NO GAYS IN CHECHYA.
Yoruba: [àmì náà ń sọ pé: Ẹ̀KA ÌṢÈDÁJỌ́ TI ORÍLẸ̀-ÈDÈE RUSSIA Ò RÍ ÀWỌN AṢE-ÌBÁLÒPỌ̀-AKỌ-ÀTI-AKỌ NÍ CHECHYA.

English: THEY ARE THERE: IN PRISONS AND IN GRAVES.
Yoruba: WỌ́N WÀ NÍBẸ̀: NÍNÚ ÀWỌN ỌGBÀ Ẹ̀WỌ̀N ÀTI IBOJÌ-ÒKÚ.

English: #SAVELGBTINRUSSIA HOMOPHOBIA=FASCISM
Yoruba: #SAVELGBTINRUSSIA Ẹ̀TANÚ ÌBÁLÒPỌ̀-LÁÀÁRÍN-AKỌ-ÀTI-AKỌ = ÌJỌBA AFIPÁMÚNI

English: In April 2017, Novaya Gazeta reported that the authorities of Chechnya, a troubled Muslim republic in the south of Russia ruled by a former warlord Ramzan Kadyrov, was waging a brutal campaign of repressions against its LGBT population.
Yoruba: Nínú oṣù Igbe 2017, Novaya Gazeta jábọ̀ pé àwọn aláṣẹ ní Chechnya, ti ìlú oníjọba Ìmọ́lẹ̀ tí ó ń rí ìdààmú jù ní gúúsù Russia tí ajagun fẹ̀yìntì Ramzan Kadyrov, ń ṣe olóríi rẹ̀, ń ṣe ìpolongo tí ó rorò tí ó ń tako ìtẹ̀mọ́lẹ̀ àwọn ènìyàn tí í ṣe LGBT tí ó ń gbé nínúu rẹ̀.

English: Recent reports said the "purge" has been intensifying, with at least two victims dead and dozens held in illegal detention.
Yoruba: Ìròyìn tí ó jáde ní àìpẹ́ sọ pé "ìfọ̀mọ́ " náà le gidi gan-an ni, pẹ̀lú ikú èèyàn méjì ó kéré tán àti ogunlọ́gọ̀ àwọn tí ó wà ní àtìmọ́lé tí ó lòdì sí òfin.

English: #FreeAmade: Journalist arrested and tortured after reporting on violence in northern Mozambique
Yoruba: #FreeAmade: Akọ̀ròyìn tí a mú tí a sì dá lóró lẹ́yìn tí ó kọ ìròyìn lórí ìwà jàgídí jàgan tí ó ń ṣẹlẹ̀ ní Àríwá Mozambique

English: Survivors who lost relatives and houses rest outside following the June 5 attack in the village of Naunde in Cabo Delgado, Mozambique.
Yoruba: Àwọn ẹni-orí-kó-yọ tí wọ́n pàdánù ẹbí àti ilé ń sinmi níta gbangba lẹ́yìn ìkọlù ọjọ́ 5 oṣù Òkúdù ní abúlé Naunde ní Cabo Delgado nílùú Mozambique.

English: Photo by Borges Nhamire, used with permission.
Yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ Borges Nhamira pẹ̀lú àṣẹ ìlò.

English: Mozambican journalist Amade Abubacar was arrested on January 5, while reporting on a trend of violent attacks on small villages in Mozambique's province of Cabo Delgado.
Yoruba: Wọ́n mú akọ̀ròyìn Mozambique kan ní ọjọ́ 5 oṣù Ṣẹẹrẹ níbi tí ó ti ń jábọ̀ ìròyìn nípa ìkọlù tí ó ń dé bá àwọn abúlé kéréje ní ìgbèríko Cabo Delgado ní Mozambique.

English: Located in northern Mozambique, Cabo Delgado is rich with natural resources, such as ruby, charcoal and natural gas, found in the Rovuma Basin.
Yoruba: Cabo Delgado wà ní àríwá orílè-èdè Mozambique, ó kún fún àwọn ohun àlùmọ́nì bí i òkúta iyebíye, èédú àti afẹ́fẹ́ gáàsì tí wọ́n rí ní Rovuma, ilẹ tí omí yí ká.

English: Some observers say the group coordinating the attacks intends to begin trafficking these resources.
Yoruba: Àwọn olùkíyèsí sọ pé ẹgbẹ́ tí ó ń darí ìkọlù yìí ní i lọ́kàn láti máa jí àwọn ohun àlùmọ́nì yìí kó.

English: Since October 2017, multiple attacks have been carried out in different districts of Cabo Delgado by what appears to be the same rogue group.
Yoruba: Láti oṣù Ọ̀wàrà 2017, àìmọye ìkọlù ni ó ti wáyé ní oríṣiríṣìí ìgbèríko ní Cabo Delgado láti ọwọ́ àwọn ẹgbẹ́ jàndùkú kan náà.

English: Many media have reported on the attacks, but state officials have been unwilling to comment on or confirm evidence in these cases.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn iléeṣẹ́ ìròyìn ni wọ́n ti jábọ̀ lórí àwọn ìkọlù yìí ṣùgbọ́n kò tilẹ̀ wu àwọn ìjọba láti sọ̀rọ̀ lé e tàbí kí wọ́n fi ìdí àrídájú ẹ̀rí múlẹ̀ nínú àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ yìí.

English: In 2018, more than one hundred people were prosecuted together in relation to these crimes. Their trial is expected to end this year.
Yoruba: Ní 2018, èèyàn tó lé lọ́gọ́rùn-ún ni wọ́n bá ṣẹjọ́ lórí àwọn ọ̀ràn yìí. Ó yẹ kí ẹjọ́ọ wọn ó parí lọ́dún yìí.

English: #FreeAmade: campaign to release Mozambican journalist
Yoruba: #FreeAmade: Ìpolongo láti gba Akọ̀ròyìn Mozambique sílẹ̀

English: Amade Aoubacar works with the Mozambican Social Communication Institute and as a journalist with news site Zitamar and the local radio station, Nacedje.
Yoruba: Amade Abubacar ń ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú Mozambican Social Communication Institute, ó sì ń ṣiṣẹ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bí akọ̀ròyìn pẹ̀lú ibùdó ìròyìn orí ayélujára Zitamar àti iléeṣẹ́ ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ìbílẹ̀ Nacedje.

English: The journalist was arrested and detained by Mozambican federal police on January 5, while photographing survivors of an attack in Cabo Delgado.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọlọ́pàá ìjọba àpapọ̀ Mozambique mú akọ̀ròyìn náà ní ọjọ́ 5 níbi tí ó ti ń ya àwòrán àwọn ẹni-orí-kó-yọ nínú ìkọlù kan ní Cabo Delgado, wọ́n sì tì í mọ́lé.

English: Amade was then taken to a military quarter of the Defense Forces of Mozambique in the district of Mueda, despite not being a member of the armed forces.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn náà, wọ́n mú Amade lọ sí ibùdó àwọn ológun Mozambique ní ìgbèríko Mueda láìjẹ́ ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ ológun.
